[[File:Indoor_Environmental_Quality_Global_Alliance_logo.jpg|thumb|right|IEQ-GA logo]]
The '''Indoor Environmental Quality Global Alliance (IEQ-GA)''' was initiated in 2014 <ref>American Society of Heating, Refrigerating and Air-Conditioning Engineers - ASHRAE: "[http://www.nxtbook.com/nxtbooks/ashrae/ashraeinsights_201408/ ASHRAE Insights, August 2014]"</ref><ref>Jessica Lyons Hardcastle, "[http://www.environmentalleader.com/2014/07/11/indoor-environmental-quality-alliance-formed/ Indoor Environmental Quality Alliance Formed]", Environmental Leader, July 2014</ref><ref>Governo Law Firm, "Newly Formed Alliance: Premier Resource for Indoor Environmental Quality", July 2014</ref> aiming to improve the actual, delivered indoor environmental quality in buildings through coordination, education, outreach and advocacy. The alliance works to supply information, guidelines and knowledge on the [[Building science|indoor environmental quality (IEQ)]] in buildings and workplaces,<ref>BUILD UP energy solutions for better buildings, "[http://www.buildup.eu/news/41608 International Societies form Indoor Environmental Quality – Global Alliance (IEQ-GA)]", 2014</ref> and to provide occupants in buildings and workplaces with an acceptable indoor environmental quality (([[indoor air quality]] (IAQ), thermal conditions, visual quality, and acoustical quality)) and help promote implementation in practice of knowledge from research on the field.
The group has already begun work to collect and critique IEQ standards and is organising and presenting programmes at the conferences of member organisations<ref>ASHRAE: "[http://www.techstreet.com/ashrae/products/1899131#jumps SEMINAR 8 Indoor environmental quality: a global and holistic perspective, part 1]", 2015</ref><ref>ASHRAE: "[http://www.techstreet.com/ashrae/products/1899132#jumps SEMINAR 8 Indoor environmental quality: a global and holistic perspective, part 2]", 2015</ref><ref>[[Air Infiltration and Ventilation Centre|Air Infiltration and Ventilation Centre - AIVC]]: "[http://www.aivc.org/news/indoor-environmental-quality-global-alliance-first-sessions-june-2015-ashrae-annual-conference Indoor Environmental Quality Global Alliance first sessions at the June 2015 ASHRAE Annual conference]", September 2015</ref><ref>[[Air Infiltration and Ventilation Centre|Air Infiltration and Ventilation Centre - AIVC]], "[http://www.aivc.org/sites/default/files/36-AIVC-program.pdf 36th AIVC Conference Programme]", September 2015</ref> and others.
The Alliance was officially launched on June 29, 2014 during [[ASHRAE]]’s 2014 Annual Conference in [[Seattle]]; a [[memorandum of understanding]] was signed and the Alliance was formed.<ref>[[venticool]]: "[http://venticool.eu/international-societies-form-indoor-environmental-quality-global-alliance-ieq-ga/ International Societies form Indoor Environmental Quality – Global Alliance] (IEQ-GA)", 2014</ref> Bill Bahnfleth, ASHRAE’s 2013-2014 president, appointed an ad-hoc committee to look at ways for industry groups to cooperate and address aspects of indoor environmental quality and health.<ref>ASHRAE: "[https://www.ashrae.org/communities/indoor-environmental-quality-global-alliance-ieq-ga Indoor Environmental Quality--Global Alliance (IEQ-GA)]", 2015</ref>
== Partners and governmental organisations == Founding members of the Indoor Environmental Quality Global Alliance include organisations that broadly deal with the indoor environments as well as those specialised primarily in [[Indoor Air Quality]](IAQ). The Alliance’s current partners include the American Industrial Hygiene Association (AIHA), the [[Air Infiltration and Ventilation Centre]] (AIVC), [[ASHRAE|the American Society of Heating, Refrigerating and Air-Conditioning Engineers (ASHRAE)]] the Air & Waste Management Association (A&WMA), the Indoor Air Quality Association (IAQA), and the Federation of European Heating and Air-Conditioning Associations ([https://www.rehva.eu/ REHVA]) <ref>ASHRAE, "[https://www.ashrae.org/File%20Library/Communities/Memoranda%20of%20Understanding/IEQ-GA-MOU.pdf Memorandum of Understanding- Indoor Environmental Quality – Global Alliance (IEQ-GA)]", Retrieved August 2018</ref>. The Alliance is also supported by governmental organisations such as the [[World Health Organization]].<ref>Chartered Institution of Building Services Engineers (CIBSE): "[http://www.cibsejournal.com/archive/PDFs/CIBSE-Journal-2014-08.pdf Industry seeks to redress IAQ balance]", CIBSE Journal August 2014</ref>

'''Ionic transfer''' is the transfer of ions from one liquid phase to another. This is related to the [[phase transfer catalyst]]s which are a special type of [[liquid-liquid extraction]] which is used in [[Chemical synthesis|synthetic]] [[chemistry]].
For instance [[nitrate]] [[anion]]s can be transferred between water and [[nitrobenzene]]. One way to observe this is to use a [[cyclic voltammetry]] experiment where the liquid-liquid interface is the working [[electrode]]. This can be done by placing secondary electrodes in each phase and close to interface each phase has a [[reference electrode]]. One phase is attached to a potentiostat<ref>[http://www.consultrsr.com/resources/pstats/ Potentiostats - Their Care and Feeding<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060613050453/http://consultrsr.com/resources/pstats/ |date=2006-06-13 }}</ref> which is set to zero volts, while the other [[potentiostat]] is driven with a triangular wave. This experiment is known as a polarised Interface between Two Immiscible Electrolyte Solutions ([[ITIES]]) experiment.
==References== {{reflist}} == See also == [[Diffusion potential]] [[Category:Physical chemistry]] [[Category:Ions]]

{{Refimprove|date=December 2009}} [[File:Purified Viruses.jpg|right|thumb|100px|Viruses purified by isopycnic centrifugation— a density gradient was formed during high speed centrifugation of a solution of [[caesium chloride]] and the two virus types come to rest at points corresponding to their density. The tube is about 10cm long.]]
An '''isopycnic surface''' is a surface of constant density inside a [[fluid]].
In [[geology]], Isopycnic surfaces occur especially in connection with [[craton]]s which are very old geologic formations at the core of the [[continent]]s, little affected by [[tectonic]] events. These formations are often known as [[Shield (geology)|shields]] or [[Platform (geology)|platforms]]. These formations are, relative to other [[Lithosphere|lithospheric]] formations, cooler and less dense but much more isopycnic.<ref name="urlSN">{{cite web |url=http://www.sciencenews.org/view/feature/id/66927/title/Continental_Hearts |title=Continental Hearts – Science News |author=Charles Petit |authorlink= |date=18 December 2010 |publisher=Science News |pages=22–26 |archiveurl=|archivedate= |accessdate=2011-01-08 }}</ref>
Isopycnic surfaces contrast with [[wikt:isobaric|isobaric]] or [[isothermal]] surfaces, which describe surfaces of constant pressure and constant temperature respectively. It is common in conversational use to hear isopycnic surfaces referred to simply as "iso-density" surfaces, which while strictly incorrect, is nonetheless abundantly more clear.
The term "isopycnic" is commonly encountered in the fluid dynamics of compressible fluids, such as in meteorology and geophysical fluid dynamics, astrophysics, or the fluid dynamics of explosions or high Mach number flows. It may also be applied to other situations where a continuous medium has smoothly-varying density, such as in the case of an inhomogeneous colloidal suspension. In general isopycnic surfaces will occur in fluids in hydrostatic equilibrium coinciding with equipotential surfaces formed by gravity.
Isopycnic typically describes surfaces, not processes. Unless there is a flux of mass into or out of a control volume, a process which occurs at a constant density also occurs at a constant volume and is called an isochoric process and not an isopycnic process.
The term "isopycnic" is also encountered in biophysical chemistry, usually in reference to a process of separating particles, subcellular [[organelle]]s, or other substances on the basis of their density. Isopycnic centrifugation refers to a method wherein a density gradient is either pre-formed or forms during high speed centrifugation. After this gradient is formed particles move within the gradient to the position having a density matching their own (this is in fact an incorrect description of the exact physical process but does describe the result in a meaningful way). This technique is extremely powerful.
==References== {{Reflist}}
==See also== *[[isopycnic centrifugation]] * [[wikt:isosteric|Isosteric]]

[[Image:Hurricane Nora Remnants 1997.JPG|thumb|right|250px|The remnants of [[Hurricane Nora (1997)|Hurricane Nora]] over the [[Southwestern United States]]]] [[Arizona]] has been affected by [[tropical cyclone|hurricanes]] on numerous occasions. Usually, these storms originate in the [[Tropical cyclone basins#Northeast Pacific Ocean|eastern Pacific Ocean]], make landfall in the [[Mexico|Mexican]] states of [[Baja California]] or [[Sonora]], and dissipate before crossing into the United States. Thus, in most cases, it is only the tropical cyclones' remnant moisture that produces heavy rainfall—and in some occasions, flooding—in portions of Arizona. However, approximately every five years, a tropical cyclone retains sufficient strength to enter the state as a [[Tropical cyclone#Intensities of tropical cyclones|tropical storm]] or a [[tropical depression]]. Arizonans can expect indirect [[flash flood]]s caused by the remnants of tropical cyclones to occur about every two years. Tropical cyclones in Arizona are not common, since the [[Trade wind|predominant wind pattern]] steers most storms that form in the Eastern Pacific either parallel or away from the Pacific coast of northwestern Mexico. As a result, most storms that could affect Arizona are carried away from the United States, with only 6% of all Pacific hurricanes entering US territory.{{cite web|first=Kristen L.|last=Corbosiero|title=The Contribution of Eastern North Pacific Tropical Cyclones to the Warm Season Rainfall Climatology of the Southwestern United States|year=2003|publisher=[[University of Albany]]|accessdate=2011-07-23|url=http://www.atmos.ucla.edu/~kristen/monsoon/monsoon.html |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20060505070334/http://www.atmos.albany.edu/student/kristen/monsoon.html |archivedate = 2006-05-05 |deadurl=yes}} Not all Arizona hurricanes originate from the Pacific Ocean, however; in July 2008 an [[Atlantic hurricane]] named [[Hurricane Dolly (2008)|Hurricane Dolly]] produced rainfall in the eastern portion of the state, and another Atlantic storm reached Arizona as a tropical depression. Many, but not all, of these systems also [[List of California tropical storms|impacted California]]. Despite their rarity, hurricanes are among Arizona's most significant weather makers. In years when Arizona is affected by a tropical cyclone, these can be responsible for up to 25% of the rainfall in areas along the [[Colorado River]]. Arizona hurricanes are also responsible for torrential rains in localized areas, with the state's 24-hour rainfall record—{{convert|11.97|in|mm}} of precipitation—occurring during [[Hurricane Nora (1997)|Hurricane Nora]]'s [[landfall (meteorology)|landfall]] in 1997. The heavy rainfall can trigger extensive flash floods, such as the ones produced by the remnants of [[October 1983 Southwest United States floods|Tropical Storm Octave]] in 1983, or the lingering moisture from [[Tropical Storm Emilia (2006)|Tropical Storm Emilia]] in 2006. ==Climatology== {{bar graph|float=right | title = Number of storms affecting Arizona | data_max = 25 | label_type = Month | data_type = Number of storms | label1 = June | data1 = 2 | label2 = July | data2 = 2 | label3 = August | data3 = 12 | label4 = September | data4 = 21 | label5 = October | data5 = 10 }} Tropical cyclones are not common over Arizona, but on average, a tropical storm or a tropical depression enters the state approximately every five years. However, indirect [[flash flood]]s caused by the remnants of tropical cyclones are more common, as they tend to occur about every two years.{{cite web|author=National Weather Service, Tucson Regional Office|title=Tropical cyclones in Arizona|accessdate=2011-07-21|url=http://www.wrh.noaa.gov/twc/tropical/tropical.php}} Storms that approach the southwestern United States, and by extension Arizona, generally form closer to the Mexican shoreline than average, making them more likely to recurve northwards under the influence of an approaching [[trough (meteorology)|trough]]. These troughs tend to extend farther to the south during the latter part of the Pacific hurricane season, in the period between late August and early October. These pronounced troughs thus produce a [[synoptic scale|synoptic-scale]] flow that is conducive to steering hurricanes towards the southwestern United States.{{cite journal|last=Corbosiero|first=Kristen L.|author2=Dickinson, Michael J. |author3=Bosart, Lance F. |title=The Contribution of Eastern North Pacific Tropical Cyclones to the Rainfall Climatology of the Southwest United States|journal=[[Monthly Weather Review]]|date=August 2009|volume=137|issue=8|pages=2415–2435|doi=10.1175/2009MWR2768.1|bibcode = 2009MWRv..137.2415C }} The infusions of tropical moisture from Arizona-bound tropical cyclones can be a significant portion of the rainfall in the region. In years when hurricanes approach Arizona, eastern and northern portions of the state receive on average 6–8% of the [[North American Monsoon|monsoon-season]] precipitation from tropical systems and their remnants. This percentage rises towards the southwestern corner of the state, which can receive up to a quarter of its monsoon-season rainfall from tropical cyclones. ==Storms== Tropical storms are one of Arizona's main sources of rainfall, as they infuse the [[North American Monsoon|monsoon over the southwestern United States]] with moisture, producing large-scale floods in occasions.{{cite web | title=Hydrologic Conditions in Arizona During 1999–2004: A Historical Perspective | publisher=[[United States Geological Survey]] | author = Arizona Water Science Center | accessdate=2006-03-20 |date=September 2005 | url=http://pubs.usgs.gov/fs/2005/3081/pdf/FS2005-3081WEB.pdf | format = PDF}} However, all of the storms that have impacted Arizona have formed in the latter parts of the [[Pacific hurricane season]], and only storm remnants have affected the state before August. {{Saffir-Simpson|right}} {| class = "wikitable sortable" |+ class="navbox-title" style="border: 1px #aaa solid; padding: 0.2em;"| '''Chronology of tropical cyclones in Arizona'''

!October 15, 2018 |} ==Storm systems== {{Wettest tropical cyclones in Arizona|align=right}} Several of these tropical cyclones have caused deaths or heavy property damage, usually due to flooding caused by rain. ===Before 1960=== Records of [[Pacific hurricane|tropical cyclones in the East Pacific]] before 1950 are sparse, but there were still several storms that produced rainfall over Arizona in this period. *August 1921: The first known tropical disturbance to affect the state occurred when a remnant low of a tropical cyclone moved into the western portions of the state.{{cite news | author = Williams, Jack | url = https://www.usatoday.com/weather/whhcalif.htm | title = Background: California's tropical storms | date = May 17, 2005 | newspaper = [[USA Today]] | accessdate = 2008-05-16}} * September 1921: A tropical depression that had tracked parallel to the Mexican coastline moved into Arizona, causing heavy rainfall on September 30.{{cite journal | url = http://docs.lib.noaa.gov/rescue/mwr/057/mwr-057-02-0043.pdf | title = Tropical Cyclones of the Eastern North Pacific Ocean | journal = [[Monthly Weather Review]] | author = Hurd, Willis E. |date=February 1929 | volume = 57 | issue = 2 | accessdate = 2008-05-16 | format = PDF}} This tropical storm caused more than three inches of rainfall along the [[Colorado River]] valley, with {{convert|3.65|in|mm|lk=on}} of rain reported in [[Yuma, Arizona|Yuma]]. Throughout the state, [[Flagstaff, Arizona|Flagstaff]] saw {{convert|1.50|in|mm}} of rainfall, while {{convert|1.24|in|mm}} of precipitation fell in [[Prescott, Arizona|Prescott]], {{convert|0.68|in|mm}} in [[Tucson, Arizona|Tucson]], and {{convert|0.56|in|mm}} in [[Phoenix, Arizona|Phoenix]]. * September 1926: Five years later, the remnants of another September storm hit the state, but this time the precipitation was heaviest on the southeastern portion of the state. The 1926 storm caused over {{convert|5.00|in|mm}} of rain in the vicinity of [[Douglas, Arizona|Douglas]]. * September 1927: The remnants of another tropical system caused {{convert|1|–|2|in|mm}} of rainfall throughout the state. * June 1929: The [[Atlantic hurricane reanalysis]] project discovered that a rare [[North Atlantic tropical cyclone|Atlantic hurricane]] reached the eastern part of the state as a tropical depression.{{hurdat-ATL}}{{cite web|last=Christopher W. Landsea|title=A Reanalysis of the 1921 to 1930 Atlantic Hurricane Database|url=http://www.aoml.noaa.gov/hrd/Landsea/19211930jc-main.pdf|publisher=[[Atlantic Oceanographic and Meteorological Laboratory]]|accessdate=2011-07-21|page=34|date=May 2011 | format = PDF|display-authors=etal}} Damage from this storm, if any, is unknown. * August 1935: The remnants of an unnamed tropical storm that landed on Southern California caused torrential rain and flooding across Arizona, especially along the [[Santa Cruz River (Arizona)|Santa Cruz River]] and Rillito Creek on Southern Arizona. The rainfall from the storm contributed to an extremely wet month of August, which still holds the monthly rainfall record at the National Weather Service office in Tucson, as {{convert|5.61|in|mm}} of rainfall fell during the month. * September 1939: Two tropical systems entered the state during the month. On September 4, the remnants of a former hurricane entered southwest Arizona, near Yuma. More than {{convert|5.00|in|mm}} of precipitation fell in northwest Arizona, with many parts of the state collecting more than an inch of rain. This same system produced more than twice the average annual rainfall in [[Imperial Valley (California)|Imperial Valley, California]]. On the 11th, the remnants of a separate system also passed over southwest Arizona. *August 1951: No tropical cyclones are known to have affected Arizona in the 1940s. However, in the 1950s, the remnants of two more storms affected the state. On August 24, 1951, the moisture from a hurricane that made landfall in [[Baja California]] moved over the state, producing more than {{convert|5.00|in|mm}} of precipitation over southwestern Arizona. Flagstaff saw {{convert|4.00|in|mm}} of rain, with similar totals measured at Prescott ({{convert|3.95|in|mm|disp=x|; }}) and Phoenix ({{convert|3.24|in|mm|disp=x|; }}). The storm also washed out several roadways near [[Gila Bend, Arizona|Gila Bend]], isolating the city from motorists. Overall, the storm caused $750,000 (1951 [[USD]]) in property damage. *July 1954: Three years later, the remnants of another hurricane moved over Arizona from the south during the month of July. Damage from this storm is unknown. ===1960s=== * September 1962: Remnant moisture from [[1962 Pacific hurricane season#Tropical Storm Claudia|Tropical Storm Claudia]] caused severe flash floods in the vicinity of Tucson, with {{convert|5|to|7|in|mm}} of precipitation falling over the headwaters of the [[Arroyo (creek)|washes]] of Santa Rosa, Jackrabbit, and [[Brawley Wash|Brawley]] during a 14- to 15-hour period. Over {{convert|7|in|mm}} of rainfall also fell near the [[Arizona-Sonora Desert Museum]]. The ensuing flood of the [[Santa Cruz River (Arizona)|Santa Cruz River]] and its tributaries produced a path of destruction about {{convert|100|mi|km}} long and up to {{convert|8|mi|km}} wide. Santa Rosa Wash conveyed {{convert|53100|cuft/s|m3/s|lk=on}} at its peak; Los Robles Wash carried up to {{convert|32600|cuft/s|m3/s|abbr=on}}, while the Santa Cruz River proper peaked at {{convert|9200|cuft/s|m3/s|abbr=on}}. The washes and rivers reached depths of up to {{convert|20|ft|m}}, and overflowed its banks in places by {{convert|1|to|6|ft|m}}. Flooding from the storm inundated the towns of [[Marana, Arizona|Marana]] and [[Sells, Arizona|Sells]], both in [[Pima County, Arizona|Pima County]]. Total damage in Pima and [[Pinal County, Arizona|Pinal]] Counties exceeded $11 million (1962 USD). * September 1964: The next storm to affect the state was [[1964 Pacific hurricane season#Tropical Storm Tillie|Tropical Storm Tillie]] in 1964. Although the storm remained at sea, its residual moisture was advected over southern Arizona, allowing a passing [[cold front]] to trigger widespread showers and thunderstorms on the evening of September 9. Tucson received {{convert|3.05|in|mm}} of rainfall in a 24-hour period between September 9–10,{{cite journal|last=Green|first=Raymond, A.|title=The Weather and Circulation of September 1964|journal=Monthly Weather Review|date=December 1964|volume=92|issue=12|pages=601–606|doi=10.1175/1520-0493(1964)092<0601:TWACOS>2.3.CO;2|bibcode = 1964MWRv...92..601G }} and two locations—one in the [[Catalina Mountains|Catalina Mountain foothills]] and one near [[Sahuarita, Arizona|Sahuarita]]—recorded {{convert|6.75|in|mm}} of precipitation. Coupled with rain during the previous week, the Santa Cruz River produced heavy runoff, with peak flows of {{convert|15900|cuft/s|m3/s|abbr=on}} recorded near [[Cortaro, Arizona|Cortaro]]. * September 1965: The following year, the remnants of [[1965 Pacific hurricane season#Hurricane Emily|Hurricane Emily]] crossed into Arizona from Baja California. Any damage from the storm is not known. * September 1966: The remnants of [[Tropical Storm Kirsten (1966)|Kirsten]] caused {{convert|1.26|in|mm}} of rainfall in [[Nogales, Arizona|Nogales]].{{cite web|author=National Weather Service, Tucson Regional Office|title=Hurricane Kirsten 1966|accessdate=2011-07-21|url=http://www.wrh.noaa.gov/twc/tropical/kirsten_1966.htm}} * August 1967: [[1967 Pacific hurricane season#Hurricane Katrina|Hurricane Katrina]] brought heavy rainfall into the southern portion of the state as a tropical depression.{{cite web|author=National Weather Service, Tucson Regional Office|title=Hurricane Katrina 1967|accessdate=2011-07-21|url=http://www.wrh.noaa.gov/twc/tropical/katrina_1967.htm}} The decaying storm produced about {{convert|2|in|mm|sigfig=2}} of rainfall across southern Arizona. The peak recorded rainfall occurred at [[Wellton, Arizona|Wellton]], where {{convert|4.78|in|mm}} were measured between September 1 and 2. Yuma recorded {{convert|1.88|in|mm}} within a 24-hour period; that was the heaviest rainfall recorded in a four-year period, and was more than the normal rainfall that the city receives during the entire fall season.{{cite journal|last=Wagner|first=A. James.|title=The Weather and Circulation of September 1967|journal=Monthly Weather Review|date=December 1967|volume=95|issue=12|pages=956–966|doi=10.1175/1520-0493(1967)095<0956:AMOCRW>2.3.CO;2|bibcode = 1967MWRv...95..956W }} * August 1968: Two storms approached Arizona in 1968. The first was [[1968 Pacific hurricane season#Tropical Storm Hyacinth|Tropical Storm Hyacinth]] in August. It reached the southeastern corner of the state as a tropical depression, and produced showers and thunderstorms over the eastern portion of the state.{{cite journal|last=Denney|first=William J.|title=The Eastern Pacific Hurricane Season of 1968|journal=Monthly Weather Review|date=March 1969|volume=97|issue=3|pages=207–224|doi=10.1175/1520-0493(1969)097<0207:TEPHSO>2.3.CO;2|bibcode = 1969MWRv...97..207D }} * October 1968: The last storm to impact Arizona during the decade was [[Hurricane Pauline (1968)|Hurricane Pauline]], which added high amounts of moisture ahead of a cold front in early October. The added [[atmospheric instability|instability]] in the atmosphere allowed the cold front to produce [[severe thunderstorm]]s, including an [[Fujita scale|F2 tornado]] that wrecked several homes and caused $250,000 (1968 USD) in damage when it touched down in [[Glendale, Arizona|Glendale]].{{cite web|author=National Weather Service, Tucson Regional Office|title=Hurricane Pauline 1968|accessdate=2011-07-21|url=http://www.wrh.noaa.gov/twc/tropical/pauline_1968.htm}}{{cite web|title=Event Report for Arizona: Maricopa County|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~5557|publisher=National Climatic Data Center|accessdate=2011-07-21|year=1968}}{{dead link|date=April 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} ===1970s=== [[File:Heather 1977 rainfall.gif|thumb|right|The rainfall produced by [[1977 Pacific hurricane season#Hurricane Heather|Hurricane Heather]] was concentrated along the United States–Mexico border.]] *September 1970: The remnants of [[Tropical Storm Norma (1970)|Tropical Storm Norma]] became Arizona's deadliest storm when they contributed to the disaster known as the "Labor Day storm of 1970". As Norma dissipated, moisture from the cyclone was entrapped in a large extratropical low. Much of the southern and central parts of the state saw {{convert|2|to|5|in|mm}} of rainfall, and mountainous locations saw between {{convert|8|to|11.4|in|mm}}. Much of the region saw extensive flash flooding that killed 23 people and caused significant damage.{{cite web|author=National Weather Service, Tucson Regional Office|title=Tropical Storm Norma 1970|accessdate=2011-07-21|url=http://www.wrh.noaa.gov/twc/tropical/norma_1970.htm}} *October 1971: The following year, [[Hurricane Irene–Olivia|Hurricane Olivia]] produced over {{convert|2|in|mm}} of rainfall across Arizona,{{cite journal|volume=99|issue=12|work=[[Monthly Weather Review]]|publisher=[[American Meteorological Society]]|page=986|date=December 1971|accessdate=2009-06-07|title=Weather and Circulation of September 1971|url=http://ams.allenpress.com/perlserv/?request=res-loc&uri=urn%3Anoaa%3Apdf%3Afile%3Amwr-099-12-0980.pdf|format=PDF|author=Robert E. Taubensee}} triggering flash flood warnings throughout the region.{{cite news|author=Staff writer|title=90-MPH Hurricane Hits North Carolina, Causes Floods, Power Outages|date=September 30, 1971|newspaper=[[The Blade (Toledo)|The Blade]]|accessdate=2011-07-21|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=nclOAAAAIBAJ&sjid=3AEEAAAAIBAJ&dq=hurricane%20olivia%20west&pg=7460%2C4939994|page=4}} Pinal Ranch reported {{convert|5.33|in|mm}} of precipitation, while [[Mount Lemmon]] measured {{convert|3.81|in|mm}}.{{cite web|author=National Weather Service, Tucson Regional Office|title=Hurricane Olivia 1971|accessdate=2011-07-21|url=http://www.wrh.noaa.gov/twc/tropical/olivia_1971.htm}} Olivia's remnants also caused three major power outages near Yuma and produced flooding that resulted in the closure of a portion of [[U.S. Route 95]].{{cite web|author=Loren Listiak|work=The Yuma Daily Sun|title=Heavy Storm Sneaks Into Town|date=September 29, 1971}} In [[Navajo County, Arizona|Navajo]] and [[Pinal County, Arizona|Pinal]] counties, the rainfall damaged roads, bridges, sewers, and homes, which amounted to about $250,000 in repair work for the state of Arizona.{{cite web|author=Pinal County Public Works |title=Summary of Historical Hazards Impacting Pinal County Communities |accessdate=2009-06-14 |url=http://ci.show-low.az.us/departments/public_works/MultiHazardMitigationPlan/Appendix%20F/HistoricalHazards_Navajo.pdf |format=PDF |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070929150653/http://ci.show-low.az.us/departments/public_works/MultiHazardMitigationPlan/Appendix%20F/HistoricalHazards_Navajo.pdf |archivedate=2007-09-29 |df= }} *October 1972: [[1972 Pacific hurricane season#Hurricane Joanne|Hurricane Joanne]] entered Arizona as a tropical storm before dissipating near [[Flagstaff, Arizona|Flagstaff]]. Many areas of the state received between {{convert|1|to|3|in|mm}} of rainfall, with isolated locations receiving over {{convert|5|in|mm}}. The Nogales Highway Bridge over the Santa Cruz River was washed away by the flooding.{{cite web|author=National Weather Service, Tucson Regional Office|title=Hurricane Joanne 1972|accessdate=2011-07-21|url=http://www.wrh.noaa.gov/twc/tropical/joanne_1972.htm}} The heavy rain from Joanne saturated the soils for a later storm that produced flooding that caused $10 million (1972 [[United States dollar|USD]]) in property damage and eight deaths. * September 1976: On September 11, [[Hurricane Kathleen (1976)|Hurricane Kathleen]] entered southern California, producing tropical-storm-force winds over western and possibly southern Arizona. Yuma reported [[maximum sustained wind]]s of {{convert|57|mph|km/h}} and gusts of {{convert|76|mph|km/h}} before the measuring station lost power.{{cite web|author=National Weather Service, Tucson Regional Office|title=Hurricane Kathleen 1976|accessdate=2011-07-21|url=http://www.wrh.noaa.gov/twc/tropical/kathleen_1976.htm}} The winds from Kathleen killed a man when a gust of wind blew a palm tree down onto his mobile home. Severe flooding and hailstorms also resulted. While most of the rainfall from the storm fell in California,{{cite web | author = Roth, David | title = Hurricane Kathleen — September 7–12, 1976 | url = http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/tropical/rain/kathleen1976.html | publisher = [[Weather Prediction Center]] | work = Tropical Cyclone Rainfall Climatology | year = 2008 | accessdate = 2008-05-15}} {{convert|2.87|in|mm}} fell at the [[Davis Dam]] on the [[Colorado River]]. * October 1976: The next month, [[Hurricane Liza (1976)|Hurricane Liza]] brought light rain to the state, with the state maximum being {{convert|1.48|in|mm}} on Willow Beach. *August 1977: [[1977 Pacific hurricane season#Hurricane Doreen|Hurricane Doreen]] caused severe flooding in [[Yuma County, Arizona|Yuma County]] and near [[Bullhead City]]. A rain gauge near the city of Yuma saw more than {{convert|7|in|mm}} of precipitation during the storm.{{cite web | author = Roth, David | title = Hurricane Doreen — August 15–18, 1977 | url = http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/tropical/rain/doreen1977.html | publisher = [[Weather Prediction Center]] | work = Tropical Cyclone Rainfall Climatology | year = 2008 | accessdate = 2008-05-15}} * October 1977: The remnants of [[1977 Pacific hurricane season#Hurricane Heather|Hurricane Heather]] caused {{convert|8.30|in|mm}} of rain in [[Nogales, Arizona|Nogales]].{{cite web | author = Roth, David | title = Hurricane Heather — October 5–8, 1977 | url = http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/tropical/rain/heather1977.html | publisher = [[Weather Prediction Center]] | work = Tropical Cyclone Rainfall Climatology | year = 2008 | accessdate = 2008-05-15}} Extensive [[bank erosion]] occurred across southeastern Arizona, as rivers crested over their [[100-year flood]] levels, and 400 people were forced to evacuate their homes. Total damage from the storm was assessed at $15 million (1977 USD).{{cite web|author=National Weather Service, Tucson Regional Office|title=Hurricane Heather 1977|accessdate=2011-07-21|url=http://www.wrh.noaa.gov/twc/tropical/heather_1977.htm}} ===1980s=== {{see also|October 1983 Southwest United States floods}} [[Image:Octave 1983 rainfall.gif|thumb|right|Rainfall due to [[Tropical Storm Octave (1983)|Tropical Storm Octave]] throughout its track]] The 1980s saw destructive tropical cyclones pass through the state, as was the case with the previous decade. *October 1983: A weather system, including moisture from [[Tropical Storm Octave (1983)|Tropical Storm Octave]], caused torrential rains over a ten-day period. The largest precipitation total occurred in [[Mount Graham]], which saw {{convert|12.00|in|mm}} of rain overall.{{cite web | author = Roth, David | title = Remains of Octave — September 29-October 4, 1983 | url = http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/tropical/rain/octave1983.html | publisher = [[Weather Prediction Center]] | work = Tropical Cyclone Rainfall Climatology | year = 2008 | accessdate = 2008-05-15}} The downpour caused record floods in the [[San Francisco River|San Francisco]], [[Gila River|Gila]], [[San Pedro River (Arizona)|San Pedro]], and Santa Cruz rivers. The latter breached its banks near [[Red Rock, Pinal County, Arizona|Red Rock]], and by its intersection with [[Interstate 8]], had flooded an area over {{convert|8|mi|km}} wide. Fourteen people drowned, 975 were injured, and roughly 10,000 people were left homeless after the flooding ended. The amount of damage from the disaster was put at $370 million (year unknown) USD. Other cities in the state also saw heavy rain, with {{convert|9.83|in|mm}} of precipitation measured at [[Nogales, Arizona|Nogales]], {{convert|6.67|in|mm}} at [[Safford, Arizona|Safford]], {{convert|6.40|in|mm}} at Tucson, {{convert|3.93|in|mm}} at [[Flagstaff, Arizona|Flagstaff]], {{convert|2.65|in|mm}} at Phoenix, and {{convert|2.62|in|mm}} at Prescott. *September 1984: [[Hurricane Norbert (1984)|Hurricane Norbert]] entered Arizona as a weakening tropical depression. Sustained winds of {{convert|20|to|30|mph|km/h|sigfig=1}} were recorded in the Tucson area. Modest rainfall occurred throughout south-central to northeast Arizona, with most locations reporting between {{convert|1|to|2|in|mm}} of rain. However, [[Kitt Peak]] reported a 30-hour storm rainfall total of {{convert|4.15|in|mm}}.{{cite web|author=National Weather Service, Tucson Regional Office|title=Hurricane Norbert 1984|accessdate=2011-07-21|url=http://www.wrh.noaa.gov/twc/tropical/norbert_1984.htm}} *October 1984: The following month, the remnants of [[Hurricane Polo (1984)|Hurricane Polo]] caused about {{convert|1|in|mm}} of rain over southern and eastern Arizona, with Nogales reporting {{convert|1.93|in|mm}} of precipitation.{{cite web|author=National Weather Service, Tucson Regional Office|title=Hurricane Polo 1984|accessdate=2011-07-21|url=http://www.wrh.noaa.gov/twc/tropical/polo_1984.htm}} *October 1989: [[Flash flood]]ing produced by [[Hurricane Raymond (1989)|Hurricane Raymond]] caused $1.5 million (1989 USD) in damage in the state.{{cite web | author = [[National Hurricane Center]] | url = http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/archive/storm_wallets/epacific/ep1989-prelim/raymond/ | title = Preliminary Report: Hurricane Raymond, 25 September–5 October 1989 | publisher = [[National Oceanographic and Atmospheric Administration]] | year = 1989 | accessdate = 2008-05-15}} Raymond passed over Arizona as a [[tropical depression]], and produced heavy rainfall on the southeastern portion of the state, with {{convert|4.72|in|mm}} of rain falling in Nogales.{{cite web | author = Roth, David | title = Hurricane Raymond — October 4–7, 1989 | url = http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/tropical/rain/raymond1989.html | publisher = [[Weather Prediction Center]] | work = Tropical Cyclone Rainfall Climatology | year = 2008 | accessdate = 2008-05-15}} About three-quarters of the streets in [[Willcox, Arizona|Willcox]] were flooded in up to {{convert|2|ft|m}} of water, and sustained winds of {{convert|25|to|35|mph|abbr=on}} were reported throughout the southeastern corner of the state.{{cite web|author=National Weather Service, Tucson Regional Office|title=Hurricane Raymond 1989|accessdate=2011-07-21|url=http://www.wrh.noaa.gov/twc/tropical/raymond_1989.htm}} ===1990s=== During the 1990s, several tropical systems affected Arizona even after losing all tropical characteristics. However, two hurricanes survived long enough to reach Arizona while still considered [[tropical cyclone|tropical systems]]. * June 1990: The moisture from [[1990 Pacific hurricane season#Hurricane Boris|Boris]] in 1990 produced {{convert|3.28|in|mm}} of rainfall on the [[Santa Rita Mountains]].{{cite web | author = Roth, David | title = Hurricane Boris — June 7–11, 1990 | url = http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/tropical/rain/boris1990.html | publisher = [[Weather Prediction Center]] | work = Tropical Cyclone Rainfall Climatology | year = 2008 | accessdate = 2008-05-15}} * August 1990: The remnants of [[Hurricane Diana]] entered Arizona and quickly dissipated, though no rainfall was report throughout the state. *August 1992: [[Hurricane Lester (1992)|Hurricane Lester]], reached the state as a tropical storm, and caused over {{convert|5|in|mm}} of precipitation near Phoenix and Tucson. The center of circulation of Lester passed near Tucson on August 24, producing sustained winds of {{convert|31|mph|km/h|abbr=on}} at [[Tucson International Airport]]; the airport also reported gusts of up to {{convert|45|mph|km/h|abbr=on}}, and a drop in [[atmospheric pressure|central barometric pressure]] to 999 [[Bar (unit)|mbar]] (29.52 [[Inch of mercury|inHg]]).{{cite web|author=National Weather Service, Tucson Regional Office|title=Hurricane Lester 1992|accessdate=2011-07-21|url=http://www.wrh.noaa.gov/twc/tropical/lester_1992.htm}} Much of the rest of the state reported over {{convert|1|in|mm}} of rain as a result of Lester,.{{cite web | author = Roth, David | title = Hurricane Lester — August 19–27, 1992 | url = http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/tropical/rain/lester1992.html | publisher = [[Weather Prediction Center]] | work = Tropical Cyclone Rainfall Climatology | year = 2008 | accessdate = 2008-05-15}} with a peak precipitation measurement of {{convert|5.5|in|mm}} at [[Cascabel, Arizona|Cascabel]]. * August 1993: [[Hurricane Hilary (1993)|Hilary]]'s remnants caused flash flooding in Pima County after {{convert|3.75|in|mm}} of rain fell on [[Green Valley, Arizona|Green Valley]], and {{convert|3.50|in|mm}} of precipitation was recorded at [[Organ Pipe Cactus National Monument]].{{cite web|author=National Weather Service, Tucson Regional Office|title=Hurricane Hilary 1993|accessdate=2011-07-21|url=http://www.wrh.noaa.gov/twc/tropical/hilary_1993.htm}} * August 1995: [[1995 Pacific hurricane season#Hurricane Flossie|Flossie]]'s remnants dumped over {{convert|3|in|mm}} of rain over Tucson; one woman died as she tried to cross a flooded stream, and 11 other motorists were stranded in the city.{{cite news|author=Associated Press|date=1995-08-13|newspaper=[[Los Angeles Times]]|title=1 dead in storm flooding Tucson|accessdate=2011-01-31|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1995-08-12/news/mn-34253_1_flood-kills-motorist}} Damage from the storm in [[Arizona]] totaled to $5 million (1995 USD; ${{Formatprice|{{Inflation|US|5000000|1995}}}} {{#time:Y}} USD).{{cite web|publisher=National Climatic Data Center|year=1995|title=Event Report for Arizona: Pima County|accessdate=2011-01-31|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~189430}}{{dead link|date=April 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} * September 1995: That same year, [[Hurricane Ismael|Ismael]] produced most of its damage south of the state, but light rainfall fell over [[Cochise County, Arizona|Cochise County]],{{cite web | author = Roth, David | title = Hurricane Ismael — September 12–17, 1995 | url = http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/tropical/rain/ismael1995.html | publisher = [[Weather Prediction Center]] | work = Tropical Cyclone Rainfall Climatology | year = 2008 | accessdate = 2008-05-15}} with the highest reported rainfall being {{convert|1.44|in|mm}}.{{cite web | author = Roth, David | title = Tropical Cyclone Rainfall for the West | url = http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/tropical/rain/tcwest.html | publisher = [[Weather Prediction Center]] | work = Tropical Cyclone Rainfall Climatology | year = 2008 | accessdate = 2008-05-15}} * September 1997: [[Hurricane Nora (1997)|Hurricane Nora]], the second storm to reach the state while still retaining tropical characteristics, struck the state in late September and was responsible for the 24-hour rainfall record in the state. Nora produced {{convert|11.97|in|mm}} of rainfall over the [[Harquahala Mountains]] in Western Arizona, causing some flash flooding in the area.{{cite web|author=Flood Control District of [[Maricopa County]]|year=1997|title=TS Nora Storm Report|accessdate=2006-02-26|url=http://156.42.96.39/alert/nora/nora_rpt.html|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20010223010517/http://156.42.96.39/alert/nora/nora_rpt.html|archivedate=2001-02-23|df=}} Near Phoenix, rainfall from the storm caused the Narrows Dam, a small [[earthen dam]], to fail; localized rainfall amounts of up to {{convert|3|in|mm}} occurred throughout the state.{{cite journal|last=Farfán|first=Luis M.|author2=Zehnder, Joseph A. |title=An Analysis of the Landfall of Hurricane Nora (1997)|journal=[[Monthly Weather Review]]|date=August 2001|volume=129|issue=8|pages=2073–2088|doi=10.1175/1520-0493(2001)129<2073:AAOTLO>2.0.CO;2|bibcode = 2001MWRv..129.2073F }} Nora also caused 12,000 people to lose electric power in Yuma.{{cite web|author=Carter, Rebecca | year=2002 | title=Tropical Storm Impacts on Arizona and New Mexico | accessdate=2006-03-03 | publisher=Climate Assessment for the Southwest Project, Institute for the Study of Planet Earth, University of Arizona | url=http://www.climas.arizona.edu/files/climas/pdfs/feature-articles/2002_aug_tropicalstorms.pdf |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20060926225918/http://www.ispe.arizona.edu/climas/forecasts/articles/tropical_Aug2002.pdf |archivedate = 2006-09-26 | format = PDF}} Nora is believed to be the strongest tropical storm to strike Arizona, as it produced sustained winds of {{convert|50|to|60|mph|km/h|abbr=on}} over Yuma.{{cite web|author=National Weather Service, Tucson Regional Office|title=Hurricane Nora 1997|accessdate=2011-07-21|url=http://www.wrh.noaa.gov/twc/tropical/nora_1997.htm}} Nora caused $150–200 million (1997 [[United States dollar|USD]]) in agricultural losses in Arizona.{{cite web|author=National Drought Mitigation Center|title=Reported Effects of the 1997–98 El Niño|publisher=University of Nebraska-Lincoln|accessdate=2006-02-26 | url=http://www.drought.unl.edu/whatis/elninoanalysis.pdf|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090304213132/http://www.drought.unl.edu/whatis/elninoanalysis.pdf|archivedate=2009-03-04|format=PDF}} * August 1998: The remnants of [[1998 Pacific hurricane season#Tropical Storm Frank|Tropical Storm Frank]] produced up to {{convert|2|in|mm}} of rainfall in parts of the state. *September 1998: The following month, [[Hurricane Isis (1998)|Hurricane Isis]]'s remnants dropped more than {{convert|2|in|mm}} of rainfall across southern [[Arizona]], resulting in some flash flood warnings and flooding on roadways.{{cite web | author = Roth, David | title = Hurricane Isis — September 1–5, 1998 | url = http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/tropical/rain/isis1998.html | publisher = [[Weather Prediction Center]] | work = Tropical Cyclone Rainfall Climatology | year = 2008 | accessdate = 2008-05-15}}{{cite news | agency=Associated Press | date=1998-09-05 | title=Isis fizzles but makes for a wet Arizona weekend }} Isis also caused up to {{convert|3|in|mm}} across the [[Santa Catalina Mountains|Santa Catalina]] and [[Rincon Mountains]] that surround Tucson. However, there was no flooding reported in the area, and Tucson International Airport reported only {{convert|1.1|in|mm}} as a result of the storm.{{cite web|author=Glueck |year=1998 |title=September 1998 climate report for Tucson |publisher=Tucson, Arizona National Weather Service |accessdate=2007-02-08 |url=http://www.wrh.noaa.gov/twc/climate/monthly/sep98.php |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061015002429/http://www.wrh.noaa.gov/twc/climate/monthly/sep98.php |archivedate=2006-10-15 |df= }} ===2000s=== [[File:Javier 2004 rainfall.gif|thumb|right|[[Hurricane Javier (2004)|Hurricane Javier]] produced heavy precipitation in Arizona.]] The last decade saw no storms reach Arizona while retaining [[Warm core|tropical characteristics]]; however, numerous remnant lows caused heavy rainfall and flooding throughout the state. *October 2000: The remnants of the first system, [[2000 Pacific hurricane season#Tropical Storm Olivia|Tropical Storm Olivia]], produced heavy flash floods in spite of Olivia losing tropical characteristics while located 600 miles (965 km) west-southwest of [[Cabo San Lucas|Cabo San Lucas, Baja California Sur]]. However, after being captured by an extratropical cyclone, the remnant low produced widespread heavy rains, with {{convert|1.5|to|4|in|mm}} of rain falling over most of southeastern Arizona; [[Hereford, Arizona|Hereford]] saw {{convert|8.64|in|mm}} of rain.{{cite web|author=National Weather Service, Tucson Regional Office|title=Tropical Storm Olivia 2000|accessdate=2011-07-21|url=http://www.wrh.noaa.gov/twc/tropical/olivia_2000.htm}} *October 2001: [[Hurricane Juliette (2001)|Hurricane Juliette]] dissipated in the Gulf of California, and brought only trace amounts of rainfall to the southern half of the state;{{cite web|author=National Weather Service, Tucson Regional Office|title=Tropical Storm Juliette 2001|accessdate=2011-07-21|url=http://www.wrh.noaa.gov/twc/tropical/juliette_2001.htm}} the largest amount recorded occurred near [[Patagonia, Arizona|Patagonia]], where {{convert|0.90|in|mm}} fell. * August 2003: Two years later, the remnants of [[Hurricane Ignacio (2003)|Hurricane Ignacio]] produced rainfall over southern Arizona. About 40 residences in [[Catalina, Arizona|Catalina]] were evacuated due to the risk of flash flooding after {{convert|2|in|mm}} of rainfall fell over the [[Aspen Fire]] burn area.{{cite web|author=National Weather Service, Tucson Regional Office|title=Hurricane Ignacio 2003|accessdate=2011-07-21|url=http://www.wrh.noaa.gov/twc/tropical/ignacio_2003.htm}} * September 2003: That same year, [[Hurricane Marty (2003)|Hurricane Marty]] brought locally heavy rains to extreme southwestern Arizona in September; in spite of this, there were no reports of flooding from the storm. The highest rain total was {{convert|2.83|in|mm}} at [[Organ Pipe Cactus National Monument]].{{cite web | author = Roth, David | title = Hurricane Marty — September 21–26, 2003 | url = http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/tropical/rain/marty2003.html | publisher = [[Weather Prediction Center]] | work = Tropical Cyclone Rainfall Climatology | year = 2008 | accessdate = 2008-05-15}} * September 2004: [[Hurricane Javier (2004)|Javier]] produced heavy rain throughout the state, helping to alleviate a prolonged drought in the [[Southwestern United States]].{{cite web|url=http://droughtmonitor.unl.edu/archive/2004/drmon0921.htm |title=U.S. Drought Monitor |author=Rippey, Brad |publisher=[[United States Department of Agriculture]] |date=September 21, 2004 |accessdate=2011-08-02 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120328103113/http://droughtmonitor.unl.edu/archive/2004/drmon0921.htm |archivedate=March 28, 2012 |df= }} The heaviest rainfall occurred at Walnut Creek, which saw a total of {{convert|7.00|in|mm}} of precipitation during the storm.{{cite web | author = Roth, David | title = Hurricane Javier — September 18–21, 2004 | url = http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/tropical/rain/javier2004.html | publisher = [[Weather Prediction Center]] | work = Tropical Cyclone Rainfall Climatology | year = 2008 | accessdate = 2008-05-15}} The Tucson airport saw rainfall of {{convert|0.37|in|mm}}, while the [[University of Arizona]] reported {{convert|0.89|in|mm}} of rain. The rain from Javier flooded several roads in the city and, combined with frequent [[lightning]], forced the university to delay one of its football games.{{cite news | url = http://www.azstarnet.com/sn/monsoon/39628 | title = Tucson area gets welcome soaking | author = Swedlund, Eric | newspaper = [[The Arizona Daily Star]] | date = September 19, 2004 | accessdate = 2010-09-11 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070929091307/http://www.azstarnet.com/sn/monsoon/39628 |archivedate = 2007-09-29}} * July 2006: The remnants of [[Tropical Storm Emilia (2006)|Tropical Storm Emilia]] produced an influx of tropical moisture over Arizona, triggering a week-long period of disturbed weather in late July. On July 25, a slow-moving [[severe thunderstorm]] dropped several inches of rainfall in a few hours, causing the closure of [[Interstate 19]] when a wash flooded the roadway with running water {{convert|8|in|mm}} deep. The same storm also produced hail with a diameter of {{convert|1.75|in|mm}} north of [[Rio Rico, Arizona|Rio Rico]], and {{convert|1|in|mm}} in Patagonia, and the size of a [[Nickel (United States coin)|nickel]] in the [[Tohono O'odham Indian Reservation]]. The next day, another thunderstorm near [[Elfrida, Arizona|Elfrida]] also produced {{convert|1|in|mm|adj=on}} hail.{{cite web|author=National Weather Service, Tucson Regional Office|year=2006|title=Review of July 26, 2006 Severe thunderstorm and Flash flood event|accessdate=2011-07-23|url=http://www.wrh.noaa.gov/twc/stormreviews/2006July26.php|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080803120804/http://www.wrh.noaa.gov/twc/stormreviews/2006July26.php|archivedate=August 3, 2008|df=}} After one week of widespread rainfall over southeastern Arizona, extensive flooding began to occur. Mount Lemmon saw a 7-day rainfall total of {{convert|11.10|in|mm}}; Rillito Creek near the Catalina Mountains conveyed a record flow of {{convert|30000|cuft/s|m3/s|abbr=on}}. Other streams in the area also saw record flooding, and the Santa Cruz River exceeded flood stage in Marana. The floods caused $4 million (2006 USD) in damage.{{cite web|author=National Weather Service, Tucson Regional Office|year=2006|title=Review of July 31, 2006 Extreme Flooding event across SE Arizona including Tucson metro|accessdate=2011-07-23|url=http://www.wrh.noaa.gov/twc/stormreviews/2006July31.php|archive-url=https://archive.is/20121214001053/http://www.wrh.noaa.gov/twc/stormreviews/2006July31.php|dead-url=yes|archive-date=2012-12-14}} * September 2006: [[Hurricane John (2006)|Hurricane John]] produced about {{convert|1|in|mm}} of rain over Cochise County.{{cite web|author=National Weather Service, Tucson Regional Office|title=Hurricane John 2006|accessdate=2011-07-21|url=http://www.wrh.noaa.gov/twc/tropical/john_2006.htm}} * September 2007: [[Hurricane Henriette (2007)|Hurricane Henriette]] also produced flooding over Cochise County the following year; one woman died after trying to cross a flooded wash near [[Sierra Vista, Arizona|Sierra Vista]].{{cite web|author=National Weather Service, Tucson Regional Office|title=Hurricane Henriette 2007|accessdate=2011-07-21|url=http://www.wrh.noaa.gov/twc/tropical/henriette_2007.htm}} * July 2008: The remnants from Atlantic hurricane Hurricane Dolly caused rainfall in the eastern portion of the state, with {{convert|1.49|in|mm}} falling southwest of [[Portal, Arizona|Portal]]. * August 2008: Moisture from [[Tropical Storm Julio (2008)|Tropical Storm Julio]] developed thunderstorms across [[Arizona]], including one near [[Chandler, Arizona|Chandler]] which produced winds of 75 mph (120 km/h); the storm damaged ten small planes at [[Chandler Municipal Airport]], as well as a hangar. The damages at the airport were estimated at $1 million (2008 [[United States Dollar|USD]]).{{cite web|publisher=National Climatic Data Center|year=2008|accessdate=2009-01-19|title=Event Report for Arizona: 1 Mile South of Sun Lakes|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~692211}}{{dead link|date=April 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} The storms also dropped heavy rainfall, reaching over {{convert|1|in|mm}} in [[Gilbert, Arizona|Gilbert]].{{cite news|author=Alyson Zepeda and Megan Boehnke|date=2008-08-26|title=Monsoon storm brings rain, wind, thunder|newspaper=The Arizona Republic|accessdate=2008-08-28|url=http://www.azcentral.com/community/gilbert/articles/2008/08/26/20080826abrk-weather.html}} * September 2009: The remnants of [[Hurricane Jimena (2009)|Hurricane Jimena]] moved over Arizona on September 5. Near [[Walapai, Arizona|Walapai]], water, rock, and other debris covered many roads.{{cite web|title=Event Report for Arizona: 5 Miles North of Walapai|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~784960|publisher=[[National Climatic Data Center]]|accessdate=2011-07-01|year=2010}}{{dead link|date=April 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} In addition, several power lines were down at the [[Bullhead City, Arizona|Bullhead City Airport]].{{cite web|title=Event Report for Arizona: Bullhead City Airport|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~784961|publisher=National Climatic Data Center|accessdate=2011-07-01|year=2010}}{{dead link|date=April 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} Golf ball-sized hail ({{convert|1.75|in|mm}} in diameter) fell northwest of [[Golden Valley, Arizona|Golden Valley]]; a weather spotter's house received $5,000 in damage, with all of its windows broken and with damage to his [[weather station]] and radio equipment.{{cite web|title=Event Report for Arizona: 3 Miles West North West of Golden Valley|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~784963|publisher=National Climatic Data Center|accessdate=2011-07-02|year=2010}}{{dead link|date=April 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} In Riviera, southwest of [[Bullhead City, Arizona|Bullhead City]], seven mobile home trails were blown with many other receiving some damage due to {{convert|80|mph|km/h|abbr=on}} wind [[Wind#Measurement|gusts]]. In the same area, four people were hurt and total damage was $500,000.{{cite web|title=Event Report for Arizona: 6 Miles South of Riviera|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~785018|publisher=National Climatic Data Center|accessdate=2011-07-01|year=2010}}{{dead link|date=April 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} North of [[Mohave Valley, Arizona|Mohave Valley]], [[mudslide]]s caused two homes to be destroyed, with 9 others receiving moderate damage, and 16 other receiving minimal damage. Total damage was estimated to be at $600,000.{{cite web|title=Event Report for Arizona: 5 Miles North of Mohave Valley|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~785019|publisher=National Climatic Data Center|accessdate=2011-07-01|year=2010}}{{dead link|date=April 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} In [[Laveen, Arizona|Laveen]], {{convert|0.9|in|mm}} of precipitation fell in a 90-minute period.{{cite web|title=Event Report for Arizona: 6 Miles West North West of Phoenix Deer Valley Airport|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~784930|publisher=National Climatic Data Center|accessdate=2011-07-01|year=2010}}{{dead link|date=April 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} Heavy rain was recorded in [[Sedona, Arizona|Sedona]], thus blocking traffic on [[Arizona State Route 179|State Route 179]].{{cite web|title=Event Report for Arizona: 1 Mile North West of Sedona|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~784995|publisher=National Climatic Data Center|accessdate=2011-07-01|year=2010}}{{dead link|date=April 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} in [[Prescott, Arizona|Prescott]], street flooding was reported, closing [[Arizona State Route 69|State Route 69]] and the Emerald Trail.{{cite web|title=Event Report for Arizona: Prescott Airport|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~784996|publisher=National Climatic Data Center|accessdate=2011-07-01|year=2010}}{{dead link|date=April 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} In [[Quartzsite]], washes overflowed their banks, causing street flooding, and $30,000 in damage.{{cite web|title=Event Report for Arizona: 1 Mile East of Quartzsite Airport|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~785065|publisher=National Climatic Data Center|accessdate=2011-07-01|year=2010}}{{dead link|date=April 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} In Tanca, {{convert|1|in|mm}} of precipitation fell within a 30-minute period, thus causing minor flooding with one road being washed out. Damage from that flood totaled $30,000. [[Yuma, Arizona|Yuma]] also reported {{convert|1.62|in|mm}} of rain from the cyclone.{{cite web|title=Event Report for Arizona: 1 Mile West South West of Colfred|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~785062|publisher=National Climatic Data Center|accessdate=2011-07-01|year=2010}}{{dead link|date=April 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} On the afternoon of September 5, a haystack caught fire due to lighting, and was eventually responsible for an additional $20,000 in damage.{{cite web|title=Event Report for Arizona: 1 Mile East North East of Yuma|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~785063|publisher=National Climatic Data Center|accessdate=2011-07-01|year=2010}}{{dead link|date=April 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} ===2010s=== *September 3, 2013: Moisture from the remnants of [[2013 Pacific hurricane season#Tropical Storm Juliette|Tropical Storm Juliette]] fueled the monsoon across the southwestern United States, producing scattered showers and thunderstorms.{{cite news|title=U.S. Drought Monitor Report for the Week Ending Sept. 3 (Text)|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2013-09-06/u-s-drought-monitor-report-for-the-week-ending-sept-3-text-.html|accessdate=September 6, 2013|newspaper=Bloomberg|date=September 6, 2013}} *September 8, 2014: The remnants of [[Hurricane Norbert (2014)|Hurricane Norbert]] produced record-breaking rainfall throughout the central portion of the state. [[Chandler, Arizona|Chandler]] received {{convert|6.09|in|mm|abbr=on}} of precipitation, while [[Phoenix Sky Harbor International Airport|Phoenix Sky Harbor Airport]] recorded {{Convert|3.30|in|mm|abbr=on}} of rainfall over a seven-hour period, breaking the 75‑year‑old daily rainfall record. It was also the highest precipitation at Sky Harbor in a single calendar day, but fell short of the station's 24‑hour rainfall total.{{cite web|agency=Phoenix, Arizona National Weather Service|accessdate=September 11, 2014|date=September 9, 2014|url=http://www.wrh.noaa.gov/psr/pns/2014/September/Sep8Flooding.php|title=Record rainfall & widespread flooding across Phoenix Metro Area }} Accumulations in Chandler and [[Mesa, Arizona|Mesa]] were deemed to be a 1-in-1,000 year event while Phoenix was calculated to be a 1-in-200 year event.{{cite web|author=Hannah Bender|publisher=Property Casualty 360|date=September 12, 2014|accessdate=September 20, 2014|title=Hurricane Norbert damages expected to exceed $100 million|url=http://www.propertycasualty360.com/2014/09/12/hurricane-norbert-damages-expected-to-exceed-100-m}} Two women died, one in [[Pinal County, Arizona|Pinal County]] and one in [[Tucson, Arizona|Tucson]]; both were swept away by floodwaters in their vehicles. Waters in Tucson reached as deep as {{convert|15|ft|m|abbr=on}}.{{cite news|newspaper=Arizona Public Media|date=September 8, 2014|title=UPDATE: 2 Deaths Reported in Tucson Floods; State Emergency|accessdate=September 8, 2014|url=https://www.azpm.org/p/home-featured/2014/9/8/43706-brewer-declares-statewide-emergency-amid-storms-flooding/}} Total damage in Maricopa and La Paz Counties amounted to $17.4 million.{{cite web|author=Aprille Slutsky |publisher=Arizona Department of Emergency and Military Affairs |date=November 24, 2014 |accessdate=February 15, 2015 |title=Arizona Summer Storms brought Record Rains and Damage |url=https://dema.az.gov/adem/news/arizona-summer-storms-brought-record-rains-and-damage |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150216030646/https://dema.az.gov/adem/news/arizona-summer-storms-brought-record-rains-and-damage |archivedate=February 16, 2015 |df= }} *September 18, 2014: The remnants of [[Hurricane Odile (2014)|Hurricane Odile]] brought heavy rainfall to southeastern Arizona.{{cite web|author1=Kong, Kwan-Yin|title=Remnants of Odile Advisory Number 32|url=http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/tropical/tropical_advisories.php?storm=ODILE&adnum=32&dt=2014091803&status=remnants|publisher=Weather Prediction Center|accessdate=2015-06-03|location=College Park, Maryland|date=2014-09-17}} *June 5, 2015: The remnants of [[2015 Pacific hurricane season#Hurricane Andres|Hurricane Andres]] brought thunderstorms to Arizona, with [[Phoenix, Arizona|Phoenix]] having measurable precipitation on that day for the first time since records began in 1896.{{cite web|url=http://www.wunderground.com/blog/JeffMasters/comment.html?entrynum%3D3007 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2015-06-05 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150605162658/http://www.wunderground.com/blog/JeffMasters/comment.html?entrynum=3007 |archivedate=2015-06-05 |df= }} *June 9, 2015: Just four days after Andres brought record-breaking rain to the Desert Southwest, another low-pressure system containing the remnants of [[2015 Pacific hurricane season#Hurricane Blanca|Hurricane Blanca]] brought more record-breaking rainfall to many Arizona cities, including Tucson and Yuma.http://www.weather.com/storms/hurricane/news/hurricane-tropical-storm-blanca-baja-california-desert-southwest-jun2015 *July 18, 2015: Some of [[2015 Pacific hurricane season#Hurricane Dolores|Hurricane Dolores]]'s moisture and remnants were directed into Arizona, bringing showers and thunderstorms. Up to 1 inch of rain was recorded in some places.{{cite tweet|user=NWSTucson|author=NWS Tucson|number=621676422910705664|date=16 July 2015|title=Hurricane Dolores will direct moisture our way increasing the chances for showers and T-storms. #azwx #AZMonsoon}}/photo/1 The heavy rain triggered some flash floods and mudslides near Phoenix.http://abcnews.go.com/WNT/video/moisture-dolores-sparks-off-major-flooding-arizona-32556746 *October 1–2 2018: [[Hurricane Rosa (2018)|Hurricane Rosa]] which at that time was a tropical storm approaching Baja California, left massive rainfall within these two days. More then 2 inches of rain was recorded in some places. Many places were covered with water, some flash floods. {{Citation needed|date=October 2018}} ==See also== {{Portal|Tropical cyclones}} * [[List of Pacific hurricanes]] * [[List of Pacific hurricane seasons]] * [[List of California hurricanes]] * [[List of New Mexico hurricanes]] * [[List of wettest tropical cyclones in the United States]] ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} {{United States hurricanes}} {{featured list}} {{DEFAULTSORT:List Of Arizona Hurricanes}} [[Category:Hurricanes in Arizona| ]] [[Category:Lists of tropical cyclones in the United States|Arizona]] [[Category:Pacific hurricanes| Arizona]] [[Category:Arizona-related lists|Hurr]]

page.title: List of Sites of Special Scientific Interest in Cleveland

revision.comment: Rescuing 1 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v1.5.3) ([[User:FA RotBot|FA RotBot]])

page.title: List of earthquakes in the Philippines

revision.text:
{{Infobox | title = Earthquakes in the Philippines | image = | caption = Philippine earthquake destroying Traditional Filipino houses | label1 = Largest | data1 = {{M|w|8.3|link=y}} [[1918 Celebes Sea earthquake]] | label2 = Deadliest | data2 = {{M|w|8.0}} [[1976 Moro Gulf earthquake]] ''5,000–8,000 killed'' }} The [[Philippines]] lies along the [[Pacific Ring of Fire]], which causes the country to have frequent seismic and volcanic activity. Many earthquakes of smaller magnitude occur very regularly due to the meeting of major tectonic plates in the region. The largest was the [[1918 Celebes Sea earthquake]] with {{M|w|8.3|link=y}}. ==Spanish period== ===17th century=== * An intensity VI quake struck [[Manila]] on June 25, 1599. The quake had damaged many private buildings and the city and ruined the roof of Old [[Santo Domingo Church]]. * An intensity VIII quake struck [[Manila]] on January 2, 1600. * A quake struck [[Manila]] on January 16, 1601. The earthquake lasted about 7 minutes, and aftershocks were experienced the whole year. * An intensity VII quake struck the municipalities of [[Dulag, Leyte|Dulag]] and [[Palo, Leyte|Palo]], [[Leyte]] in December 3, 1608. * An intensity IX quake struck [[Manila]] on November 1610. It was a terrible quake that progressed from east to west. * An intensity IX quake struck [[Panay Island]] on 1620. A great number of casualties were reported in [[Capiz]] and [[Iloilo]] provinces. The earthquake changed the course of the [[Aklan River]] and damaged stone churches and their façades in [[Passi, Iloilo]]. * An intensity X quake struck [[Luzon|Northern Luzon]] on 1627. Convulsions were felt in [[Cagayan]] and [[Ilocos Norte]] provinces, the [[Bontoc, Mountain Province|Bontoc]] and [[Mountain Province#Spanish Period|Lepanto]], and central parts of the [[Cordillera Central (Luzon)|Cordillera Central]]. Other sources claimed that the [[Caraballo Mountains]] somewhat subsided. * [[1628 Camarines earthquake|An intensity IX quake]] struck [[Albay]] and [[Camarines]]Districts nearby [[Mayon Volcano]] and [[Camalig, Albay|Camalig]], not the present-day Camarines provinces. on 1628. The quake caused avalanches of [[volcanic ash|ash]]es, [[lapilli]], water and sand that swept away whole towns in Albay and Camarines. * An intensity IX quake struck [[Illana Bay]], Western [[Mindanao]] on December 21, 1636. Landslides reported along [[Illana Bay]], [[Sibuguey Bay]] and Point Flechas. * An intensity X quake struck [[Luzon|Northern Luzon]] on January 4, 1641. The quake occurred after the 1641 eruption of [[Mount Parker (Cotabato)|Mount Parker]]. Landslides and mudflow destroyed villages in [[Ilocos]] provinces, [[Cagayan]] and the [[Cordillera Central (Luzon)|Cordillera Central]]. * [[1645 Luzon earthquake|A magnitude 7.5 quake struck Luzon]] on November 30, 1645. The earthquake was then the strongest to hit the Islands since the Spanish conquest.Blair, Emma Helen and Robertson, James Alexander (1906). [https://books.google.com/books?id=JjRJxF_vcaUC&pg=PA17#v=onepage&q&f=false "The Philippine Islands 1493–1898 Vol. XXXV"], pg. 17. Arthur H. Clark Co., Cleveland. It had greatly damaged newly constructed churches and [[Manila Cathedral]], along with residential villas and buildings in the city and nearby provinces. Some 600 people were reported dead.{{cite journal | url=http://eqtap.edm.bosai.go.jp/publications/ACEE/pdf/ACEE-55.pdf | title=Philippine Historical Earthquakes and Lessons Learned |author1=Bautista, Maria Leonila P. |author2=Bautista, Bartolome C. |lastauthoramp=yes| journal=EqTAP Project}} * An intensity VIII quake struck [[Luzon]] on December 5, 1645. It was a major aftershock of the November 30, 1645 Luzon earthquake, and it had further destroyed remaining buildings in Manila and nearby towns. Aftershocks ceased around March 1646. * An intensity IX quake struck Southern Luzon on 1648. It was a very violent earthquake that wrecked many buildings. * An intensity VI quake struck [[Manila]] on May 1, 1653. * An intensity IX quake struck Southern Luzon on August 20, 1658. It was comparable to the [[1645 Luzon earthquake]], but had caused less damage on building and was less proximity from the epicenter. It had destroyed the Royal Monastery of Santa Clara, several monasteries of the [[Order of Preachers|Dominicans]] and [[Augustinian Recollects|Recollects]], the [[Society of Jesus|Jesuit]] College and episcopal palaces. * A magnitude 5.5 quake struck [[Manila]] on June 19, 1665. Only a Jesuit church experienced great damage. 19 were reported dead. * An intensity VIII struck [[Isla Verde Passage]] in February 1675. The quake destroyed many buildings in northern [[Oriental Mindoro]] and southern [[Batangas]] provinces. This led to occurrences of landslides, opening of ground fissures, and subsidence of beaches along the coast of Mindoro. * An intensity VII struck [[Manila]] on August 24, 1683. ===18th century=== * An intensity VII struck Lake Bombon (now known as [[Taal Lake]]) on September 24, 1716. It was connected with the eruption of [[Taal volcano]]; the constant volcanic activity in the area of Taal caused seismic movements. * An intensity IX struck Tayabas (now known as [[Quezon]]) in 1730. It had ruined the churches and convent in [[Mauban]] and several other churches in the province of [[Quezon|Tayabas]] and [[Laguna (province)|Laguna]]. ===19th century=== [[File:Manila Cathedral belfry after the 1880 earthquake.jpg|thumb|The belfry of [[Manila Cathedral]] after the series of destructive earthquakes of July 1880.]] * An earthquake on June 3, 1863, destroyed [[Manila Cathedral]], the ''[[Ayuntamiento de Manila|Ayuntamiento]]'' (city hall), the Governor's Palace (all three located at the time on Plaza Mayor, now [[Plaza de Roma]]) and much of the city. The residence of the Governor-General was moved to [[Malacañang Palace]] located about 3 km (1.9 miles) up the [[Pasig River]], while the other two buildings were rebuilt in place. * [[1880 Luzon earthquakes|An intensity X quake]] struck Luzon on July 14 to 25, 1880.{{cite book | title=Seismic and Volcanic Centers of the Philippine Archipelago | publisher=''Bureau of Printing'' | author=Maso, Saderra | year=1902 | location=[[Manila]] | page=16}} The quake caused severe damage to these major cities in Luzon, most significantly in Manila where a lot of buildings collapsed. Number of casualties are unknown. * A quake struck [[Lucban, Quezon]] on October 26, 1884. It destroyed churches in [[Lucban, Quezon|Lucban]], [[Tayabas (province)|Tayabas province]] (now known as [[Quezon (province)|Quezon province]]) and [[Cavinti, Laguna|Cavinti]] in Laguna province. *[[1897 Mindanao earthquakes|Two earthquakes]] struck near [[Basilan]] Island near [[Mindanao]] on September 20 and 21, 1897. Both earthquakes triggered tsunamis, with the second being quite destructive, with a maximum run-up of 7.0 m. At least 13 died as a result of the second tsunami, with a hundred or more casualties also being reported. ==American period and Post-World War II== ===Early 20th century=== * A magnitude 7.5 quake struck [[Northern Mindanao|Northeastern Mindanao]] on July 11, 1912. Damage and high intensity were experienced by towns of [[La Paz, Agusan del Sur|La Paz]], [[Bunauan, Agusan del Sur|Bunauan]], [[Veruela, Agusan del Sur|Veruela]] and [[Talacagon, Agusan del Sur|Talacogon]] in the [[Legislative district of Agusan|Agusan Valley]] where intense ground shaking, liquefaction, widespread landslides and river/lake seiches occurred.{{cite web | url=http://202.90.128.66/1999BayuganEQ/index-bayugan.html | title=June 1999 Earthquakes in Agusan del Sur, Philippines | publisher=[[Philippine Institute of Volcanology and Seismology]] | accessdate=February 7, 2012}} * The {{M|w|8.3}} [[1918 Celebes Sea earthquake|Celebes Sea earthquake]] occurred on August 15, 1918 with a maximum [[Mercalli intensity scale|Mercalli intensity]] of X (''Extreme''). The offshore shock affected the southern Philippines with high intensity shaking and a destructive tsunami that left 52 people dead. * A strong magnitude 8.0 earthquake struck [[Davao Region|Southern Mindanao]] on April 14, 1924.{{cite web |title=M 8.0 - Mindanao, Philippines |url=https://earthquake.usgs.gov/earthquakes/eventpage/iscgem910911#executive |website=USGS |accessdate=26 August 2018}} * A magnitude 7.8 [[Moment magnitude scale|Mw]] earthquake struck [[1948 Lady Caycay earthquake|Panay Island on January 25, 1948 at 1:46 AM]]. The epicenter was between the municipalities of [[Anini-y, Antique|Anini-y]] and [[Dao, Antique|Dao]] in Antique province. * An intensity VII earthquake struck [[Luzon]], mainly [[Isabela (province)|Isabela]] on December 29, 1949. Starting at 11:05 a.m., it lasted for two-and-a-half minutes. The damage was moderately destructive, causing landslides and rough waves capsizing boats, as well as fissures that spat out black water. The intensity ranged from IV to VII throughout Luzon.{{cite web | url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=U2hIAAAAIBAJ&sjid=gFUDAAAAIBAJ&pg=3907,2009367&dq=luzon+earthquake&hl=en | title=Luzon Island Shaken By Major Earthquake | publisher=''[[Evening Independent]]'' | date=December 29, 1949 | accessdate=March 15, 2012}} ===Mid to late 20th century=== * A magnitude of 7.6 earthquake struck [[1968 Casiguran earthquake|Casiguran, Aurora, on August 2, 1968]], at the depth of approximately 31 km. It was considered the most severe and destructive earthquake experienced in the Philippines during the last 20 years. 270 people were reported dead and 261 were injured. [[File:Lebak Tsunami.jpg|thumbnail|right|The damage caused by a tsunami at Barangay Tibpuan, [[Lebak, Sultan Kudarat|Lebak, Mindanao]] after the 7.9 [[Moro Gulf]] Earthquake on August 16, 1976.]] * A magnitude 7.0 quake struck [[Ragay Gulf]] on March 17, 1973. [[Calauag, Quezon]] was the worst hit, as the quake caused 98 houses totally destroyed, and 270 more were partially damaged.{{cite web | url=http://202.90.128.66/1973RagaeGulfEQ/index-ragae.html | title=Ragay Gulf Earthquake - 17 March 1973 | publisher=[[Philippine Institute of Volcanology and Seismology]] | accessdate=February 7, 2012}} * A magnitude 8.0 earthquake struck [[1976 Moro Gulf earthquake|Mindanao on August 16, 1976.]] The quake caused a devastating tsunami that had hit the 700 km coastline of the island of [[Mindanao]] bordering [[Moro Gulf]] in the [[Celebes Sea|North Celebes Sea]]. An estimated 5,000 - 8,000 people died. The major cause of the great number of casualties during the event could be attributed to the fact that the quake happened just after midnight when most people were sleeping; and a great tsunami was spawned, struck the coasts from different directions and caught the people unaware.{{cite web | url=https://earthquake.usgs.gov/earthquakes/world/historical_country.php#philippines | title=Historic World Earthquakes - Philippines | publisher=[[United States Geological Survey]] | accessdate=February 7, 2012 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100728221758/http://earthquake.usgs.gov/earthquakes/world/historical_country.php#philippines | archivedate=July 28, 2010 | df= }} * A magnitude 6.5 earthquake struck [[1983 Luzon earthquake|Laoag on August 17, 1983]], at a depth of 42 km. The quake has caused the deaths of 16 and injured 47 people.{{cite web | url=http://202.90.128.66/1983LaoagEQ/index-laoag.html | title=Laoag Earthquake - 17 August 1983 | publisher=[[Philippine Institute of Volcanology and Seismology]] | accessdate=February 7, 2012}} * {{anchor|Bohol 1990}}A magnitude 6.8 earthquake struck [[Bohol]] on February 8, 1990. Six fatalities were reported and more than 200 were injured in the event. About 46,000 people were displaced by the event and at least 7,000 among them were rendered homeless. Estimated damage to properties is amounting to [[Philippine peso|₱]]154-million.{{cite web | url=http://202.90.128.66/1990BoholEQ/index-bohol90.html | title=Bohol Earthquake - February 8, 1990 | publisher=[[Philippine Institute of Volcanology and Seismology]] | accessdate=February 7, 2012}} * A magnitude 7.1 earthquake struck [[Panay Island]] on June 14, 1990 at a depth of 15 km. Seven people died and 31 others were injured.{{cite web | url=http://202.90.128.66/1990PanayEQ/index-panay.html | title=Panay Earthquake - 14 June 1990 | publisher=[[Philippine Institute of Volcanology and Seismology]] | accessdate=February 7, 2012}} * A magnitude 7.7 earthquake struck [[1990 Luzon earthquake|Luzon on July 16, 1990]]. It caused severe damage to major cities in Luzon: [[Dagupan City]] (soil liquefaction), [[Baguio City]], and [[Cabanatuan City]]; Hyatt Terraces Baguio collapsed. 1,621 were reported dead. Damage to buildings, infrastructures, and properties amounted to at least ₱10-billion, a part of which was caused by ground rupturing. However, some houses within 1–2 m on either side of the ground rupture survived owing to their light-weight construction while those built of reinforced concrete within this zone suffered partial damage. Damage beyond 2m depended mainly on the structural integrity of the building and effects of local topography and ground conditions.{{cite web | url=http://202.90.128.66/1990LuzonEQ_Monograph/foreword.html | title=The 16 July 1990 Luzon Earthquake Ground Rupture | publisher=[[Philippine Institute of Volcanology and Seismology]] | accessdate=February 7, 2012 | author=Punongbayan, Raymundo S. et al. (Philippine Institute of Volcanology and Seismology); and Takashi Nakata, Hiroyuki Tsutsumi (Hiroshima University, Japan)}} * A magnitude 7.1 earthquake struck [[1994 Mindoro earthquake|Mindoro on November 15, 1994]] at depth of 15 km. The quake caused a tsunami killed 41 people and destroyed 1530 houses.{{cite web | url=http://www.ess.washington.edu/tsunami/specialized/events/mindoro/mindoro.html | title=1994 Mindoro Tsunami | publisher=[[Philippine Institute of Volcanology and Seismology]] | accessdate=February 7, 2012}} * A series of large earthquakes struck [[Samar]] on April 21, 1995, with four of the largest earthquakes being near magnitude 7 and the largest one registering at magnitude 7.3. The earthquakes also resulted in a small tsunami that was recorded in [[Legazpi, Albay]]. The area was hit by another earthquake of magnitude 7.0 on May 5 of the same year.{{cite magazine |author= |title=Samar Island, Philippines Earthquakes and Tsunami of April 21, 1995 |url=http://itic.ioc-unesco.org/images/stories/products_and_services/newsletter/1990-1999/1995/1995_July.pdf |magazine=Tsunami Newsletter |location=Honolulu, Hawaii |publisher=International Tsunami Information Center |date=July 1995 |access-date=August 26, 2018 }} * A magnitude 5.6 earthquake struck [[Bohol]] on May 27, 1996 at a depth of 4 km. The earthquake did not cause major damage to properties. Damage was confined to poorly built structures and/or old wooden, masonry, limestone walls of houses and buildings, generally due to ground shaking.{{cite web | url=http://202.90.128.66/1996BoholEQ/index-bohol96.html | title=Bohol Earthquake - 27 May 1996 | publisher=[[Philippine Institute of Volcanology and Seismology]] | accessdate=February 7, 2012}} * A magnitude of 5.1 struck [[Bayugan]], [[Agusan del Sur]] on June 7 and 9, 1999. The towns of [[Bayugan]] and [[Talacogon]] were the most devastated. * A magnitude 6.8 earthquake struck northwest of the coast of [[Zambales]] on December 12, 1999. The earthquake killed six people and injured 40 in Zambales, [[Pangasinan]], and [[Metro Manila]]. The quake also caused power outages throughout Manila. {{cite web |title=Philippines - Earthquake OCHA Situation Report No. 2 |url=https://reliefweb.int/report/philippines/philippines-earthquake-ocha-situation-report-no-2 |website=reliefweb |accessdate=31 August 2018}} ==21st century== ===Largest earthquakes by year=== {{Location map+|Mindanao|float=right|width=300|alt=Earthquakes in Mindanao|caption=The largest 20th century Philippine earthquakes: the [[1918 Celebes Sea earthquake]] (8.3 Mw) and the [[1976 Moro Gulf earthquake]] (8.0 Mw). The [[Moro Gulf]], part of the [[Celebes Sea]], is labeled for context.|places= {{Location map~|Mindanao|lat=6.50|long=123.00|position=left|label=
