As for the repeated entries, the [[Moro Gulf]] is a seismically active area, the location of the devastating [[1976 Moro Gulf earthquake]] which killed over 5,000 people, while [[Samar]] is near the [[Philippine Trench]]. {| class="sortable wikitable" style="font-size:100%;" |- ! Year ! Magnitude ! Location / Name ! Date |- | 2001 | 7.5 | Mindanao (SE, offshore){{cite web|url=https://earthquake.usgs.gov/earthquakes/eventpage/usp000a70h#executive|title=M 7.5 - Mindanao, Philippines|publisher=[[United States Geological Survey]]|accessdate=March 8, 2018}} | {{dts|January 1}} |- | 2002 | 7.5 | [[2002 Mindanao earthquake|Mindanao]] | {{dts|March 5}} |- | 2003 | 6.5 | Samar | {{dts|November 18}} |- | 2004 | 6.5 | Mindoro | {{dts|October 8}} |- | 2005 | 6.4 | Moro Gulf (near){{cite web|url=https://earthquake.usgs.gov/earthquakes/eventpage/usp000e583#executive|title=M 6.4 - Mindanao, Philippines|publisher=[[United States Geological Survey]]|accessdate=March 8, 2018}} | {{dts|November 30}} |- | 2006 | 6.3 | Luzon | {{dts|October 9}} |- | 2007 | 6.4 | Mindanao (SE, offshore){{cite web|url=https://earthquake.usgs.gov/earthquakes/eventpage/usp000fk9n#executive|title=M 6.4 - Philippine Islands region|publisher=[[United States Geological Survey]]|accessdate=March 8, 2018}} | {{dts|August 20}} |- | 2008 | 6.9 | Samar | {{dts|March 3}} |- | 2009 | 6.6 | Moro Gulf | {{dts|October 4}} |- | 2010 | 7.6 | [[2010 Mindanao earthquakes|Moro Gulf]] | {{dts|July 23}} |- | 2011 | 6.4 | Ilocos Region | {{dts|March 20}} |- | 2012 | 7.6 | [[2012 Samar earthquake|Samar]] | {{dts|August 31}} |- | 2013 | 7.2 | [[2013 Bohol earthquake|Bohol]] | {{dts|October 15}} |- | 2014 | 6.6 | Moro Gulf (near){{cite web|url=https://earthquake.usgs.gov/earthquakes/eventpage/usb000t20t#summary|title=M6.6 - 106km WSW of Sangay, Philippines|publisher=[[United States Geological Survey]]|date=December 2, 2014|accessdate=December 2, 2014}} | {{dts|December 2}} |- | 2015 | 6.1 | Siargao{{cite web|url=https://earthquake.usgs.gov/earthquakes/eventpage/us10002n6s#executive|title=M 6.1 - 23km NW of Santa Monica, Philippines|publisher=[[United States Geological Survey]]|accessdate=March 8, 2018}} | {{dts|July 3}} |- | 2016 | 6.3 | Tamisan (Davao Region){{cite web|title=M6.3 - 36km SE of Tamisan, Davao Region, Philippines|url=https://earthquake.usgs.gov/earthquakes/eventpage/us10006s4v#executive|publisher=[[United States Geological Survey]]|access-date=November 15, 2016|date=September 24, 2016}} | {{dts|September 24}} |- | 2017 | 6.9 | [[2017 Sarangani earthquake|Sarangani]] (Davao Region) | {{dts|April 29}} |- |} ===All large known earthquakes=== As the Philippines is subject to frequent seismic activity, to keep this list manageable, earthquakes with large magnitudes are prioritized (those with M < 6 are discouraged), unless the event has other noteworthy qualities such as causing fatalities, significant damage, or other notable consequences. * A magnitude of 7.5 quake struck [[Mindanao]] on January 1, 2001 at a depth of 33 km.{{cite web | url=http://earthquakes.findthedata.org/l/5874/Philippines-Mindanao | title=Philippines: Mindanao Earthquake, 2001 | publisher=[[National Geophysical Data Center]] | accessdate=February 7, 2012}} * A magnitude of 7.5 quake struck [[2002 Mindanao earthquake|''Central and Southern Mindanao'' on March 5, 2002]] at a depth of 31 km.{{cite web | url=http://neic.usgs.gov/neis/eq_depot/2002/2002_stats.html | title=Magnitude 7 and Greater Earthquakes in 2002 | publisher=[[United States Geological Survey]] | accessdate=February 7, 2012 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120218052601/http://neic.usgs.gov/neis/eq_depot/2002/2002_stats.html | archivedate=February 18, 2012 | df= }} At least 15 people were killed, 100 injured and 800 buildings were damaged or destroyed.{{cite web | url=https://earthquake.usgs.gov/earthquakes/eqarchives/poster/2002/20020305.php | title=Poster of the Mindanao, Philippines Earthquake of 05 March 2002 - Magnitude 7.5 | publisher=[[United States Geological Survey]] | accessdate=February 7, 2012}} * A magnitude of 6.1 quake struck [[Sultan Kudarat]] on March 6, 2002. Office of Civil Defense (OCD) records show that 8 people had died and 41 were injured due to the earthquake. It affected 7,684 families in the provinces of [[Sultan Kudarat]], [[Sarangani]], [[North Cotabato]] and [[South Cotabato]] including four cities and 17 municipalities.{{cite web | url=http://202.90.128.66/palimbang/summary.html | title=Palimbang Earthquake: Summary Report | publisher=[[Philippine Institute of Volcanology and Seismology]] | accessdate=February 7, 2012}} * A magnitude of 6.2 quake struck [[Masbate]] on February 15, 2003 at a depth of 22 km. The quake damaged major infrastructures in Masbate.{{cite web | url=http://202.90.128.66/2003masbateEQ/the%20earthquake.html | title=Masbate Earthquake: Report of Investigation | publisher=[[Philippine Institute of Volcanology and Seismology]] | accessdate=February 7, 2012}} * A magnitude of 6.5 quake struck [[Samar]] on November 18, 2003. One person was reported dead. * A magnitude of 6.5 quake struck [[Mindoro]] on October 8, 2004. * A magnitude of 6.6 quake struck [[Moro Gulf]] on October 4, 2009. * A series of quakes with the main quake's magnitude of 7.3 struck [[2010 Mindanao earthquakes|Moro Gulf on July 23–24, 2010]]. * A magnitude of 6.4 quake struck [[Ilocos Region]] on March 20, 2011. * A magnitude of 5.2 quake struck [[Valencia City, Bukidnon]] on November 8, 2011 at a depth of 1 km.{{cite web | url=http://www.phivolcs.dost.gov.ph/html/update_SOEPD/2011_Earthquake_Bulletins/November/2011_1107_0943_M52D000_B5F.html | title=Earthquake Information No. 5 | publisher=[[Philippine Institute of Volcanology and Seismology]] | accessdate=February 7, 2012}} 39 people were injured, and several establishments were damaged.{{cite web |url=http://www.abs-cbnnews.com/nation/regions/11/08/11/39-hurt-bukidnon-quake |title=39 hurt in Bukidnon quake |date=November 8, 2011 |publisher=''[[ABS-CBN News and Current Affairs|ABS-CBN News]]'' |accessdate=February 6, 2012}} * A magnitude of 6.9 quake struck [[2012 Visayas earthquake|Negros, the rest of Central Visayas, and some parts of Mindanao on February 6, 2012]], at a depth of 20 km. The quake killed people, caused major damage on infrastructures, and buildings. A tsunami alert level 2 was raised due to the quake. The quake also caused a landslide, burying a barangay. More than a thousand of aftershocks were recorded by PHIVOLCS within 2 days since the quake occurred.{{cite web | url=http://interaksyon.com/article/23783/11-killed-as-magnitude-6-9-quake-strikes-off-negros | title=Number of casualties rises as 6.9 quake strikes off Negros | publisher=''[[News5|Interaksyon]]'' | date=February 6, 2012 | accessdate=February 7, 2012 | author1=Abigail Kwok | author2=Joseph Ubalde | author3=Lira Dalangin-Fernandez | last-author-amp=yes | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120209033214/http://www.interaksyon.com/article/23783/11-killed-as-magnitude-6-9-quake-strikes-off-negros | archivedate=February 9, 2012 | df= }}{{cite web |url=http://www.mb.com.ph/articles/350496/69-magnitude-quake-jolts-negros-oriental |title=Quake Jolts Visayas |author1=Ellalyn B. De Vera |author2=Elena L. Aben |author3=Mars W. Mosqueda Jr. |last-author-amp=yes |date=February 6, 2012 |publisher=''[[Manila Bulletin]]'' |accessdate=February 6, 2012}}{{cite web | url=http://www.abs-cbnnews.com/nation/regions/02/06/12/magnitude-68-quake-jolts-negros-cebu-region | title=Strong quake jolts Negros-Cebu; fatalities rising | publisher=''[[ABS-CBN News and Current Affairs|ABS-CBN News]]'' | date=February 6, 2012 | accessdate=February 6, 2012}} According to National Disaster Risk Reduction and Management Council, as of February 18, 2012, the death toll have risen to 51 with 62 people still missing, and injuring 112 people. Most deaths came from the city of [[Guihulngan]] and [[La Libertad, Negros Oriental|La Libertad]] where landslides occurred. 63, 697 from provinces in [[Central Visayas|Region VII]] were affected by the quake. 15, 483 houses were partially or totally damaged, and a total of ₱383-million worth of damage to buildings, roads and bridges, and other infrastructures were recorded. * A magnitude of 5.9 quake struck [[Surigao City]] on March 16, 2012. Many were injured in the city for that certain day was the grand opening of Gaisano Capital Surigao. An estimated 6,000 people were in Gaisano when the earthquake happened. The earthquake caused a stampede which injured people.{{cite web | url=http://www.sunstar.com.ph/breaking-news/2012/03/16/59-magnitude-quake-sparks-stampede-surigao-211548 | title=5.9-magnitude quake sparks stampede in Surigao | publisher=''[[Sun.Star]]'' | date=March 16, 2012 | accessdate=September 4, 2012}}{{cite web | url=http://www.gmanetwork.com/news/story/251704/news/regions/phivolcs-magnitude-5-9-quake-hits-surigao-area-damage-and-aftershocks-expected | title=Phivolcs: Magnitude-5.9 quake hits Surigao area, damage and aftershocks expected | publisher=''[[GMA News and Public Affairs|GMA News Online]]'' | date=March 16, 2012 | accessdate=September 4, 2012}}{{cite web | url=http://www.rappler.com/nation/2606-quake-leads-to-stampede-at-surigao-mall | title=Quake leads to stampede at Surigao mall | publisher=''Rappler'' | date=March 16, 2012 | accessdate=September 4, 2012}} * An earthquake with magnitude 7.6 struck 106 km near [[2012 Samar earthquake|Guiuan, Eastern Samar]] on August 31, 2012. It was felt in certain areas of Visayas and Mindanao. One person died, and another one was injured in [[Cagayan de Oro City]] after being trapped in a collapsed house due to a landslide.{{cite web | url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/ap/article/ALeqM5h3yDv9wmJtgpAHrkYG4KtLbO9-zg?docId=0662357038c44f92b048c042044137b7 | title=Quake off Philippines spurs small tsunami; 1 dead | publisher=''[[Associated Press]]'' | date=September 1, 2012 | accessdate=September 4, 2012 | author=Cerojano, Teresa}} Minutes after the quake, power interruptions occurred in the affected areas. The [[National Disaster Risk Reduction and Management Council]] reported that a house in [[Agusan del Sur]] province caught fire sparked by a gas lamp that was toppled during the earthquake. It also reported that two bridges in [[Eastern Samar]], particularly the Buyayawan Bridge in Mercedes town and the Barangay Casuroy Bridge in San Julian town, were partially damaged. The Abreeza Mall in Bajada, Davao City suffered minor cracks on the floor due to the earthquake.{{cite web | url=http://www.philstar.com/nation/article.aspx?publicationsubcategoryid=63&articleid=844016 | title=One dead as 7.6-magnitude quake hits Philippines | publisher=''[[The Philippine Star]]'' | date=September 1, 2012 | accessdate=September 4, 2012}} In [[General MacArthur, Eastern Samar]], 77 homes were damaged. There were also 6 houses damaged in Barangay Casoroy, San Julian.{{cite web | url=http://www.abs-cbnnews.com/nation/regions/09/01/12/quake-damages-77-homes-e-samar-town | title=Quake damages 77 homes in E. Samar town | publisher=''[[ABS-CBN News and Current Affairs|ABS-CBN News]]'' | date=September 1, 2012 | accessdate=September 4, 2012}} In [[Balangiga, Eastern Samar]], a hospital sustained serious damage.{{cite web | url=http://www.abs-cbnnews.com/nation/regions/09/04/12/quake-severely-damages-e-samar-hospital | title=Quake severely damages E. Samar hospital | publisher=''[[ABS-CBN News and Current Affairs|ABS-CBN News]]'' | date=September 4, 2012 | accessdate=September 4, 2012}} A wall from an old building collapsed in [[Butuan City]].{{cite web | url=http://www.abs-cbnnews.com/nation/regions/09/01/12/quake-causes-panic-damage-visayas-mindanao | title=Quake causes panic, damage in Visayas, Mindanao | publisher=''[[ABS-CBN News and Current Affairs|ABS-CBN News]]'' | date=September 1, 2012 | accessdate=September 4, 2012}} The NDRRMC reported on Saturday noon there were cracks on some roads and bridges and other establishments in areas where the quake was felt.{{cite news | url=http://www.philstar.com/Article.aspx?articleId=844522&publicationSubCategoryId=200 | title=Strong quake, but minimal effects: gov't | publisher=''[[The Philippine Star]]'' | date=September 2, 2012 | agency=Xinhua | accessdate=September 4, 2012}} Most of the homes destroyed were those made of light materials, while overall damage to infrastructure remained minimal.{{cite news | url=http://www.brecorder.com/world/southeast-asia/76582.html | title=Philippine families rebuild amid further quake fears | publisher=''[[Business Recorder]]'' | date=September 2, 2012 | agency=Agence France-Presse | accessdate=September 4, 2012}} A tsunami warning of Level 3 was raised by the [[Philippine Institute of Volcanology and Seismology]], but was lifted 5 hours after the quake only caused tiny waves.{{cite news | url=http://www.foxnews.com/world/2012/08/31/7-magnitude-quake-strikes-philippines/ | title=At least 1 dead in 7.6 Philippine quake, small tsunami reported, warning canceled | publisher=''[[Fox News]]'' | date=August 31, 2012 | accessdate=September 4, 2012 | agency=Associated Press}} * A series of earthquakes, struck cities of [[Malaybalay]] and [[Valencia City, Bukidnon|Valencia]], and the sitio of [[Musuan]], [[Maramag]] in [[Bukidnon]] last September 3–4, 2012. The first quake has a magnitude of 3.4 and was felt at 06:48 PM,{{cite web | url=http://www.phivolcs.dost.gov.ph/html/update_SOEPD/2012_Earthquake_Bulletins/September/2012_0903_1048_B1.html | title=Earthquake Information: September 3, 2012 06:48:49 PM | publisher=[[Philippine Institute of Volcanology and Seismology]] | accessdate=February 7, 2012}} and was followed by magnitude 4.0 at 07:45 PM,{{cite web | url=http://www.phivolcs.dost.gov.ph/html/update_SOEPD/2012_Earthquake_Bulletins/September/2012_0903_1145_B1.html | title=Earthquake Information: September 3, 2012 07:45:48 PM | publisher=[[Philippine Institute of Volcanology and Seismology]] | accessdate=February 7, 2012}} and 4.7 at 09:21 PM.{{cite web | url=http://www.phivolcs.dost.gov.ph/html/update_SOEPD/2012_Earthquake_Bulletins/September/2012_0903_1321_B2F.html | title=Earthquake Information: September 3, 2012 09:21:04 PM | publisher=[[Philippine Institute of Volcanology and Seismology]] | accessdate=February 7, 2012}} Hours after the first three, a series of quakes occurred in 03:44 AM and in 03:52 AM. The first quake had a magnitude of 5.6 with a depth of focus of 3 km;{{cite web | url=http://www.phivolcs.dost.gov.ph/html/update_SOEPD/2012_Earthquake_Bulletins/September/2012_0903_1944_B3F.html | title=Earthquake Information: September 4, 2012 03:44:22 AM | publisher=[[Philippine Institute of Volcanology and Seismology]] | accessdate=February 7, 2012}} while the second one was recorded at a magnitude of 4.9 with a depth focus of 3 km.{{cite web | url=http://www.phivolcs.dost.gov.ph/html/update_SOEPD/2012_Earthquake_Bulletins/September/2012_0903_1952_B2F.html | title=Earthquake Information: September 4, 2012 03:52:26 AM | publisher=[[Philippine Institute of Volcanology and Seismology]] | accessdate=February 7, 2012}} The quake was felt as far as [[Cagayan de Oro]], [[Kidapawan]], [[Butuan]], and [[Cotabato City|Cotabato]] cities.{{cite web | url=http://www.philstar.com/nation/article.aspx?publicationsubcategoryid=200&articleid=845200 | title=5.6 quake jolts Bukidnon, nearby provinces | publisher=''[[The Philippine Star]]'' | date=September 4, 2012 | accessdate=September 4, 2012}}{{cite web | url=http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/263874/5-6-magnitude-quake-shakes-bukidnon | title=5.6-magnitude quake shakes Bukidnon | publisher=''[[Philippine Daily Inquirer]]'' | date=September 4, 2012 | accessdate=September 4, 2012 | author=Mangosing, Frances}} A nun was injured in Barangay Lourdes in Valencia City after the incident. Valencia City Disaster Risk Reduction and Management Council reported that 144 houses and structures were destroyed. Mayor Ignacio Zubiri of Malaybalay City reported no casualties nor damage in his city.{{cite web | url=http://bukidnonnews.net/news/2012/09/nun-injured-144-structures-houses-destroyed-in-bukidnon-quakes/ | title=Nun injured; 144 structures, houses destroyed in Bukidnon quakes | publisher=''Bukidnon News'' | date=September 4, 2012 | accessdate=September 4, 2012}} The quakes were of tectonic in origin. A total of 131 aftershocks were recorded after the 5.6 quake in September 4, 2012.{{cite web | url=http://ndrrmc.gov.ph/attachments/article/681/EQ%20Initial%201%20001.pdf | title=Initial Report re Effects of Earthquake in Maramag, Bukidnon | publisher=[[National Disaster Risk Reduction and Management Council]] | date=February 18, 2012 | accessdate=February 19, 2012 | page=17}} * A 6.2 earthquake struck off the coast of Southern Mindanao on February 16, 2013, 28 kilometers southeast of Caburan, Davao del Sur. According to the [[United States Geological Survey]], the quake struck at a depth of 98.2 km.{{cite web | url=http://www.philstar.com/headlines/2013/02/16/909659/update-magnitude-6.2-earthquake-jolts-mindanao | title=Magnitude 6.2 earthquake jolts Mindanao | publisher=''[[The Philippine Star]]'' | date=February 16, 2013 | accessdate=February 26, 2013}}{{cite web | url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2013-02-16/magnitude-6-quakes-hit-offshore-in-philippines-new-zealand.html | title=Magnitude-6 Quakes Hit Offshore in Philippines, New Zealand | publisher=''[[Bloomberg L.P.|Bloomberg]]'' | date=February 16, 2013 | accessdate=February 26, 2013 | author=Stephanie Tong}} * A 5.7 earthquake struck the island of Mindanao on June 1, 2013.{{cite web | url=http://www.sunstar.com.ph/davao/local-news/2013/06/01/strong-quake-jolts-cotabato-285321 | title=Strong quake jolts Cotabato | publisher=''[[Sun.Star|Sun Star Davao]]'' | date=June 1, 2013 | accessdate=June 3, 2013}} The quake's epicenter was located in [[Carmen, Cotabato]] and struck with a depth of 5 kilometers.{{cite web | url=http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/418697/5-7-quake-shakes-mindanao-phivolcs | title=5.7-quake shakes Mindanao—Phivolcs | publisher=''[[Philippine Daily Inquirer]]'' | date=June 1, 2013 | accessdate=June 3, 2013 | author=Frances Mangosing}}{{cite web | url=http://www.mindanews.com/top-stories/2013/06/02/magnitude-5-7-quake-felt-in-several-mindanao-areas/ | title=Magnitude 5.7 quake felt in several Mindanao areas | publisher=''Minda News'' | date=June 2, 2013 | accessdate=June 3, 2013}} The said quake injured six people, 4 of them were children, and fully or partly destroyed several houses, and some school buildings.{{cite web | url=http://www.abs-cbnnews.com/nation/regions/06/02/13/quake-destroys-30-houses-carmen-n-cotabato | title=Quake destroys 30 houses in Carmen, N. Cotabato | publisher=''[[ABS-CBN News]]'' | date=June 2, 2013 | accessdate=June 2, 2013 | author=Jasper Acosta}}{{cite web | url=http://www.mindanews.com/top-stories/2013/06/02/5-injured-in-saturdays-magnitude-5-7-quake-30-houses-partly-destroyed/ | title=5 injured in Saturday’s magnitude 5.7 quake; 30 houses partly destroyed | publisher=''Minda News'' | date=June 2, 2013 | accessdate=June 3, 2013 | author=Keith Bacongco}} It also damaged a bridge at Barangay Kimadzil, and another one at Barangay Kibudtungan.{{cite web | url=http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/419455/classes-in-quake-hit-north-cotabato-town-suspended | title=Classes in quake-hit North Cotabato town suspended | publisher=''[[Philippine Daily Inquirer]]'' | date=June 3, 2013 | accessdate=June 3, 2013 | author=Edwin Fernandez}} The quake was followed by 15 aftershocks, the last one was followed by a 4.3 quake on June 2, 2013.{{cite web | url=http://www.mb.com.ph/article.php?aid=15118&sid=1&subid=5#.Uaw760A3BqU | title=Magnitude 5.7 quake hits North Cotabato | publisher=''[[Manila Bulletin]]'' | date=June 2, 2013 | accessdate=June 3, 2013 | author=Alexander D. Lopez}} The quake caused ₱71-million worth of damage. Another quake jolted the said town after 4:00 AM on June 3, 2013. The quake was recorded at 5.7 and struck at a depth of 3 kilometers.{{cite web | url=http://www.philstar.com/nation/2013/06/03/949675/p71m-worth-properties-damaged-cotabato-quake | title=P71M worth of properties damaged in Cotabato quake | publisher=''[[The Philippine Star]]'' | date=June 3, 2013 | accessdate=June 3, 2013 | author=John Unson}} The newest quake further injured 8 more people, and damaged more houses. Classes which was slated to open on June 3, 2013, were cancelled due to a series of quakes that hit the town since June 1, 2013.{{cite web | url=http://www.mb.com.ph/article.php?aid=15255&sid=1&subid=5#.Uaw_FkA3BqU | title=DepEd suspends classes in quake-affected town of Carmen | publisher=''[[Manila Bulletin]]'' | date=June 3, 2013 | accessdate=June 3, 2013 | author=Malu Cadelina Manar}} * A [[2013 Bohol earthquake|magnitude of 7.2 earthquake struck Bohol]] on October 15, 2013 at 8:12 a.m. ([[Philippine Standard Time|PST]]).{{cite web | url=http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/507617/quake-death-toll-now-over-60 | title=Death toll from Bohol quake jumps to 85 | publisher=''[[Philippine Daily Inquirer]]'' | date=October 15, 2013 | accessdate=October 15, 2013 | author=Frances Mangosing}} Its epicenter was located {{convert|6|km}} SW of [[Sagbayan, Bohol|Sagbayan]] at a depth of {{convert|12|km}}. According to the official report by the [[National Disaster Risk Reduction and Management Council]], 222 were reported dead while 796 people were injured. Tens of thousands of structures were damaged by the earthquake. Most notable were the national historical churches in Bohol and Cebu. File:Loon Church Facade.JPG|Loon Church prior to the earthquake File:Loon 1 earthquake.JPG|The rubble that was Loon Church after the quake * A magnitude 6.1 quake struck 47 km N 47°E of Burgos (Surigao del Norte) on July 3, 2015, 2:43 pm at a depth of 26 km.http://www.phivolcs.dost.gov.ph/html/update_SOEPD/2015_Earthquake_Bulletins/July/2015_0703_0643_B2F.html * A [[2017 Surigao earthquake|magnitude 6.5 earthquake]] struck 10 km SW of [[Basilisa, Dinagat Islands]] on February 10, 2017, 10:03 pm at a depth of 15 km. Eight people were killed and 202 injured.{{Cite news|url=http://www.foxnews.com/world/2017/02/12/aftershocks-rattle-survivors-after-philippine-quake-kills-8.html|title=Aftershocks rattle survivors after Philippine quake kills 8|date=2017-02-12|work=Fox News|access-date=2017-10-01|language=en-US}} * [[Batangas]] experiences an [[2017 Batangas earthquakes|earthquake swarm]] in April 2017. A magnitude 5.5 [[2017 Batangas earthquakes|earthquake]] struck 5 km W of [[Batangas]] on April 4, 2017, 8:58 pm at a depth of 82 km. Twin earthquakes with magnitudes of 5.6 and 6.0 hit the barangays of Bagalangit and Tanauan, both in [[Mabini, Batangas]] respectively on April 8, 2017, 3:07 and 3:09 pm at a depth of 40.4 km. Damages on some buildings and houses have been reported. Several aftershocks followed. * A [[2017 Sarangani earthquake|magnitude 6.9 earthquake]] struck 47 km S 26° W of [[Sarangani]] and [[Davao Occidental]] provinces on April 29, 2017 at 4:23 am at a depth of 57 km. Five people were injured.{{Cite web|url=https://reliefweb.int/sites/reliefweb.int/files/resources/Update_on_Sitrep_No.02_re_Magnitude_7.2_Earthquake_in_Sarangani_Davao_Occidental_Issued_on_30_April_2017.pdf|title=https://reliefweb.int/sites/reliefweb.int/files/resources/Update_on_Sitrep_No.02_re_Magnitude_7.2_Earthquake_in_Sarangani_Davao_Occidental_Issued_on_30_April_2017.pdf|last=|first=|date=|website=|access-date=}} * A [[2017 Leyte earthquake|magnitude 6.5 earthquake]] struck 3 km S 16° E of [[Jaro, Leyte|Jaro]], [[Leyte]] on July 6, 2017 at 4:03 pm at a depth of 8 km. It caused island-wide blackouts in the provinces of [[Samar]], [[Bohol]], Leyte, and parts of [[Southern Leyte]] In [[Kananga, Leyte|Kananga]], a commercial building collapsed killing two persons and injuring 20 others. In [[Ormoc City]], a landslide was triggered. Four people died and 100 others were injured.{{Cite news|url=http://gulfnews.com/news/asia/philippines/four-dead-100-injured-in-leyte-s-6-5-magnitude-quake-1.2054857|title=Four dead, 100 injured in Leyte’s 6.5 magnitude quake|last=Correspondent|first=Barbara Mae Dacanay,|date=2017-07-08|work=GulfNews|access-date=2017-10-01}} * A magnitude 5.7 earthquake struck 31 km depth hypocenter of Dinagat Islands on May 10, 2018 at 19:56:58 time, that strike [[Southern Leyte]], [[Dinagat Islands]], [[Surigao Del Norte]], [[Agusan del Norte]] and [[Eastern Samar]].https://earthquake-report.com/2018/05/10/strong-earthquake-leyte-philippines-may-10-2018 ==Deadliest earthquakes== The table below is a tally of the ten deadliest recorded earthquakes in the Philippines since the 1600s: {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center; width:100%;" |- ! colspan="11" | Ten deadliest recorded earthquakes in the Philippines since the 1600s |- ! style="width: 10%;" scope="col" colspan="2" | {{M|mag}} ! style="width: 05%;" scope="col" | Origin ! style="width: 20%;" scope="col" | Location ! style="width: 15%;" scope="col" | Date ! style="width: 10%;" scope="col" | Mortality ! style="width: 10%;" scope="col" | Missing ! style="width: 15%;" scope="col" | Injured ! style="width: 10%;" scope="col" | Damage ! style="width: 05%;" scope="col" | Source |- ! 1 | 7.9 | Tectonic | [[1976 Moro Gulf earthquake|Moro Gulf]] | August 16, 1976 | 4,791 | 2,288 | 9,928 | | |- ! 2 | 7.8 | Tectonic | [[1990 Luzon earthquake|Luzon Island]] | July 16, 1990 | 1,666 | 1,000 | 3,000 < | [[Philippine peso|₱]] 10 billion | |- ! 3 | 7.5 | Tectonic | [[1645 Luzon earthquake|Luzon Island]] | November 30, 1645 | 600 < | | 3,000 < | ''Unknown'' | |- ! 4 | 7.6 | Tectonic | Mindanao | March 31, 1955 | 400 < | | ''Unknown'' | [[United States dollar|US$]]5 million |{{cite web|last1=NCEI|title=Global Significant Earthquake Database, 2150 B.C. to present|url=http://www.ngdc.noaa.gov/nndc/struts/form?t=101650&s=1&d=1|publisher=NOAA National Centers for Environmental Information|ref=NGDC}} |- ! 5 | 7.6 | Tectonic | [[1968 Casiguran earthquake|Casiguran, Aurora]] | August 2, 1968 | 271 | | 261 | | |- ! 6 | 7.2 | Tectonic | [[2013 Bohol earthquake|Bohol and Cebu]] | October 15, 2013 | 222 | 8 | 796 | [[Philippine peso|₱]] 4 billion (est.) | {{cite web|title=Massive extremely dangerous earthquake in Bohol, Philippines – At least 222 people killed, 8 missing, over 790 injured, around 4 billion PHP damage, 7 billion PHP reconstruction costs.|url=http://earthquake-report.com/2013/10/15/very-strong-earthquake-mindanao-philippines-on-october-15-2013/|publisher=Earthquake-Report.com|accessdate= October 2013|date=October 31, 2013}} |- ! 7 | 7.1 | Tectonic | [[1994 Mindoro earthquake|Mindoro]] | November 15, 1994 | 78 | | 430 | [[Philippine peso|₱]] 5.15 million | {{cite web | url=http://www.ess.washington.edu/tsunami/specialized/events/mindoro/mindoro.html | title=1994 Mindoro Tsunami | publisher=[[Philippine Institute of Volcanology and Seismology]] | accessdate=February 7, 2012}} |- ! 8 | 6.7 | Tectonic | [[2012 Visayas earthquake|Negros Oriental]] | February 6, 2012 | 51 | 62 | 112 | [[Philippine peso|₱]] 383 million | |- ! 9 | 7.8 | Tectonic | [[1948 Lady Caycay earthquake|Panay (Lady Caycay)]] | January 25, 1948 | 50 (est.) | | | [[Philippine peso|₱]] 7 million | |- ! 10 | 5.5 | Tectonic | [[Manila]] | June 19, 1665 | 19 | | | ''Unknown'' | |} ==References== {{Reflist|2}} ==External links== {{Commons category|Earthquakes in the Philippines}} {{Portal|Earthquakes}} * [http://www.phivolcs.dost.gov.ph Official website of the Philippine Institute of Volcanology and Seismology] * [http://www.phivolcs.dost.gov.ph/html/update_SOEPD/EQLatest.html Latest Earthquake Bulletin in the Philippines] * [http://www.ndrrmc.gov.ph Official website of the National Disaster Risk Reduction and Management Council] {{Earthquakes in the Philippines}} {{Asia topic|List of earthquakes in}} [[Category:Earthquakes in the Philippines| Link]] [[Category:Lists of earthquakes by country|Philippines]] [[Category:Lists of events in the Philippines|Earthquakes]]

The '''list of ecoregions in Indiana''' are listings of [[terrestrial ecoregions]] (see also, [[ecosystem]]) in the United States' State of [[Indiana]], as defined separately by the [[United States Environmental Protection Agency]] (USEPA), and the [[World Wildlife Fund]].
==USEPA== The USEPA ecoregion classification system has four levels, but only Levels I, III, and IV are shown on this list. Level I divides North America into 15 broad ecoregions (or [[biomes]]). Indiana is within the Eastern Temperate Forest environment, Level I region. Level IV ecoregions (denoted by numbers and letters) are a further subdivision of Level III ecoregions (denoted by numbers alone).<ref name=CEC>{{cite web | publisher=[[Commission for Environmental Cooperation]] | title=Ecological Regions of North America: Toward a Common Perspective | url=http://www3.cec.org/islandora/en/item/1701-ecological-regions-north-america-toward-common-perspective | year=1997 | accessdate=2013-04-07 }}</ref><ref>[http://www.plantmaps.com/interactive-indiana-ecoregions-l4-map.php Plant Maps Interactive - Indiana Ecoregions (based on EPA data)], retrieved 2013-04-07</ref><ref>[ftp://ftp.epa.gov/wed/ecoregions/in/OHINFront.pdf Ecoregions of Indiana and Ohio] USEPA</ref> *[[Corn Belt|54 Central Corn Belt Plains]] **54a - Illinois/Indiana [[Tallgrass prairie|Prairie]] **54b - [[Lake Chicago|Chicago Lake]] Plain **54c - [[Kankakee Marsh]] **54d - Sand Area *[[Corn Belt|55 Eastern Corn Belt Plains]] **55a - The Clayey, High Lime [[Till]] Plains **55b - The Loamy, High Lime Till Plains **55d - The Pre-Wisconsinan Drift Plains **55f - The [[Whitewater River (Great Miami River)|Whitewater]] Interlobate Area *[[Southern Michigan/Northern Indiana Drift Plains (ecoregion)|56 Southern Michigan/Northern Indiana Drift Plains]] **56a - The Lake Country **56b - The Elkhart Till Plains **56c - The Middle [[Tippecanoe River|Tippecanoe]] Plains **56d - The Michigan Lake Plain *[[Huron/Erie Lake Plains (ecoregion)|57 Huron/Erie Lake Plains]] **57a - The Maumee Lake Plains *[[Interior Plateau (ecoregion)|71 Interior Plateau]] **71a - The Crawford Uplands **71b - The Mitchell Plain **71c - The Norman Upland **71d - The Northern [[Kentucky bluegrass|Bluegrass]] *[[Interior River Valleys and Hills (ecoregion)|72 Interior River Valleys and Hills]] **72a - [[Wabash River|Wabash]]-Ohio Bottomlands **72b - Glaciated [[Wabash River|Wabash]] Lowlands **72c - The Southern Wabash Lowlands
==World Wildlife Fund== {| class="wikitable sortable" style="margin: 1em auto 1em auto" |- ! '''[[Terrestrial ecozone|Ecozone]]''' ! '''[[Biome]]''' ! '''Ecoregion''' ! '''State Location''' |- |- | [[Nearctic]] | [[Temperate broadleaf and mixed forests]] | [[Central U.S. hardwood forests]] | Southern Indiana |- | [[Nearctic]] | [[Temperate broadleaf and mixed forests]] | [[Southern Great Lakes forests]] | North, Central, and Eastern Indiana |- | [[Nearctic]] | [[Temperate grasslands, savannas, and shrublands]] | [[Central forest-grasslands transition]] | Western Indiana |- |}
==References== {{Reflist}}
*'''See:''' Ricketts, Taylor H; Eric Dinerstein; David M. Olson; Colby J. Loucks; et al. (1999). ''Terrestrial Ecoregions of North America: a Conservation Assessment.'' Island Press; [[Washington, DC]]
==See also== *[[Geography of Indiana]] *[[Climate of Indiana]] *[[List of ecoregions in the United States (EPA)]] *[[List of ecoregions in the United States (WWF)]]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Ecoregions in Indiana}} [[Category:Ecoregions of the United States|Indiana]] [[Category:United States science-related lists]] [[Category:Indiana geography-related lists]] [[Category:Environment of Indiana]] [[Category:Lists of ecoregions|Indiana]]

* [[Guinean forest-savanna mosaic]] * [[Mandara Plateau mosaic]] * [[Sahelian Acacia savanna]] * [[Western Sudanian savanna]]

* [[Jos Plateau forest-grassland mosaic]]

* [[Lake Chad flooded savanna]]

===Nilo-Sudan===
* [[Bight Coastal]] * [[Lake Chad Catchment]] * [[Lower Niger-Benue]] * [[Niger Delta]]
===West Coastal Equatorial===

==References== * Burgess, Neil, Jennifer D’Amico Hales, Emma Underwood (2004). ''Terrestrial Ecoregions of Africa and Madagascar: A Conservation Assessment''. Island Press, Washington DC. * Spalding, Mark D., Helen E. Fox, Gerald R. Allen, Nick Davidson ''et al.'' "Marine Ecoregions of the World: A Bioregionalization of Coastal and Shelf Areas". ''Bioscience'' Vol. 57 No. 7, July/August 2007, pp. 573–583. * Thieme, Michelle L. (2005). ''Freshwater Ecoregions of Africa and Madagascar: A Conservation Assessment''. Island Press, Washington DC. * Toham, Andre Kamdem ''et al.'', eds. (2006). ''A Vision for Biodiversity Conservation in Central Africa: Biological Priorities for Conservation in the Guinean-Congolian Forest and Freshwater Region''. World Wildlife Fund, Washington DC. Page A-52.

|- |Maize red stripe (now known as Wheat mosaic virus ||[[Wheat mosaic virus]] (WMoV) |- |Maize ring mottle ||[[Maize ring mottle virus]] (MRMV) |- |Maize rough dwarf (nanismo ruvido) ||[[Maize rough dwarf virus]] (MRDV) |- |Maize sterile stunt ||[[Maize sterile stunt virus]] (strains of [[barley yellow striate virus]]) |- |[[Maize streak]] ||[[Maize streak virus]] (MSV) |- |Maize stripe (maize chlorotic stripe, maize hoja blanca) ||[[Maize stripe virus]] |- |Maize tassel abortion ||[[Maize tassel abortion virus]] (MTAV) |- |Maize vein enation ||[[Maize vein enation virus]] (MVEV) |- |Maize wallaby ear ||[[Maize wallaby ear virus]] (MWEV) |- |Maize white leaf ||[[Maize white leaf virus]] |- |Maize white line mosaic ||[[Maize white line mosaic virus]] (MWLMV) |- |Millet red leaf ||[[Millet red leaf virus]] (MRLV) |- |Northern cereal mosaic ||[[Northern cereal mosaic virus]] (NCMV) |- |Oat pseudorosette (zakuklivanie) ||[[Oat pseudorosette virus]] |- |Oat sterile dwarf ||[[Oat sterile dwarf virus]] (OSDV) |- |Rice black-streaked dwarf ||[[Rice black-streaked dwarf virus]] (RBSDV) |- |Rice stripe ||[[Rice stripe virus]] (RSV) |- |Sorghum mosaic ||[[Sorghum mosaic virus]] (SrMV), formerly [[sugarcane mosaic virus]] (SCMV) strains H, I and M |- |Sugarcane Fiji disease ||[[Sugarcane Fiji disease virus]] (FDV) |- |Sugarcane mosaic |[[Sugarcane mosaic virus]] (SCMV) strains A, B, D, E, SC, BC, Sabi and MB (formerly MDMV-B) |- |Wheat mosaic |[[Wheat mosaic virus]] (WMoV) |- |} == References == {{Reflist}} * [https://web.archive.org/web/20070202084939/http://www.apsnet.org/online/common/names/corn.asp Common Names of Diseases, The American Phytopathological Society] {{corn}} [[Category:Maize diseases|*]] [[Category:Lists of plant diseases|Maize]]

page.title: List of pipeline accidents in the United States in 2010

revision.comment: added [[Category:2010 disasters in the United States]] using [[WP:HC|HotCat]]
revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=May 2016}}
{{Use American English|date=May 2016}} The following is a '''list of pipeline accidents in the United States in 2010'''. It is one of several [[list of pipeline accidents in the United States|lists of U.S. pipeline accidents]]. See also [[list of natural gas and oil production accidents in the United States]]. {{expand list|date=April 2013}} __NOTOC__ <!--begin temporary compact toc--> <!-- something nicer-looking and more navigable should be done here; this is a temporary TOC to ease navigation --> <!-- | bgcolor=#dddddd align=center colspan=11 | See also – [[#References|References]] --> <!--end compact toc-->
== Incidents ==
This is not a complete list of all pipeline accidents. '''For natural gas alone''', the Pipeline and Hazardous Materials Safety Administration (PHMSA), a United States Department of Transportation agency, has collected data on more than 3,200 accidents deemed serious or significant since 1987.
A "significant incident" results in any of the following consequences: * fatality or injury requiring in-patient hospitalization * $50,000 or more in total costs, measured in 1984 dollars * liquid releases of five or more barrels (42 US gal/barrel) * releases resulting in an unintentional fire or explosion
PHMSA and the National Transportation Safety Board (NTSB) post incident data and results of investigations into accidents involving pipelines that carry a variety of products, including natural gas, oil, diesel fuel, gasoline, kerosene, jet fuel, carbon dioxide, and other substances. Occasionally pipelines are repurposed to carry different products.<ref>Data sets of PHMSA Pipeline Safety-Flagged Incidents for 1986-2001, 2002-2009, and 2010-2017 can be downloaded from the tab by that name on the PHMSA's Pipeline Incident Flagged Files page at https://www.phmsa.dot.gov/data-and-statistics/pipeline/pipeline-incident-flagged-files, accessed 2018.01.10. PHMSA Corrective Action Orders are at https://primis.phmsa.dot.gov/comm/reports/enforce/CAO_opid_0.html. PHMSA Pipeline Failure Investigation Reports are at https://www.phmsa.dot.gov/safety-reports/pipeline-failure-investigation-reports. NTSB Pipeline Accident Reports are at https://www.ntsb.gov/investigations/AccidentReports/Pages/pipeline.aspx.</ref>
* On January 2, [[Enbridge]]'s Line 2 ruptured near [[Neche, North Dakota]], releasing about 3,784 barrels of crude oil, of which 2,237 barrels of were recovered. The cause was a material defect.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://primis.phmsa.dot.gov/comm/reports/operator/OperatorIM_opid_11169.html?nocache=5280#_Incidents_tab_3 |title=PHMSA: Stakeholder Communications |publisher=Primis.phmsa.dot.gov |date= |accessdate=April 2, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130602185558/http://primis.phmsa.dot.gov/comm/reports/operator/OperatorIM_opid_11169.html?nocache=5280 |archivedate=June 2, 2013 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=CPF No. 3-2010-5001H |url=http://primis.phmsa.dot.gov/comm/reports/enforce/documents/320105001H/320105001H_CAO_01192010.pdf |accessdate=28 November 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170215110410/https://primis.phmsa.dot.gov/comm/reports/enforce/documents/320105001H/320105001H_CAO_01192010.pdf |archivedate=February 15, 2017 }}</ref> * On January 7, a gas pipeline exploded near [[Barksdale Air Force Base]], Louisiana, in January, killing a pipeline employee.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.airforcetimes.com/news/2010/01/ap_airforce_barksdale_explosion_010710/ |archive-url=https://archive.is/20120720212631/http://www.airforcetimes.com/news/2010/01/ap_airforce_barksdale_explosion_010710/ |dead-url=yes |archive-date=July 20, 2012 |title=Pipeline explosion at Barksdale kills civilian – Air Force News | News from Afghanistan & Iraq |publisher=Air Force Times|agency=Associated Press|date= January 7, 2010 |accessdate=April 2, 2013}}</ref> * On February 1, a plumber trying to unclog a sewer line in [[St. Paul, Minnesota]] ruptured a gas service line that has been "cross bored" through the house's sewer line. The plumber and resident escape the house moments before as an explosion and following fire destroyed the house. The Minnesota Office of Pipeline Safety ordered that gas utility, Xcel, to check for more cross bored gas lines. In the following year, 25,000 sewer lines inspected showed 57 other cross bored gas lines. In [[Louisville, Kentucky]], 430 gas line cross bores were found in {{convert|200|mi|km}} of a sewer project, including some near schools and a hospital. The NTSB had cited such cross bore incidents as a known hazard since 1976.<ref>{{cite web |title=A year later, gas line checks continue |publisher=StarTribune.com |url=http://www.startribune.com/local/115153164.html |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130203061257/http://www.startribune.com/local/115153164.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=February 3, 2013 |accessdate=May 14, 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.crossboresafety.org/history.htm |title=History |publisher=CrossboreSafety.org |date=February 9, 1999 |accessdate=April 2, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130417114346/http://www.crossboresafety.org/history.htm |archivedate=April 17, 2013 }}</ref> * On February 7, a power plant explosion occurred at the Kleen Energy Systems, killing 5 and injuring a dozen. * On February 25, a natural gas liquids (NGL) pipeline ruptured near [[Pond Creek, Oklahoma]], releasing over {{convert|575,000|USgal|L}} of NGL's, and forcing road closures. There was no fire.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://enidnews.com/localnews/x1004926657/Highway-closed-for-gas-leak |title=Highway closed for gas leak " Local news " The Enid News and Eagle, Enid, OK |publisher=Enidnews.com |date=February 25, 2010 |accessdate=April 2, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://primis.phmsa.dot.gov/comm/reports/operator/OperatorIM_opid_32109.html?nocache=3139#_OuterPanel_tab_2 |title=PHMSA: Stakeholder Communications |publisher=Primis.phmsa.dot.gov |date= |accessdate=April 2, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131028010325/http://primis.phmsa.dot.gov/comm/reports/operator/OperatorIM_opid_32109.html?nocache=3139 |archivedate=October 28, 2013 }}</ref> * On March 1, at about 8:10 am, Mid-Valley Pipeline identified a release of crude oil in the manifold area of the Mid-Valley tank farm in [[Longview, Texas]]. Crude oil was observed "gushing" from the soil in the manifold area. About 198 barrels of crude oil were estimated to have been released and 196 barrels were recovered from the secondary containment area within Mid-Valley's site.<ref>[http://www.phmsa.dot.gov/staticfiles/PHMSA/PipelineFailureReports/Mid-Valley%20Pipeline%20HL%20TX%202010-03-01%20508.pdf Failure Investigation Report – Mid-Valley Pipeline Internal Corrosion] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120402093120/http://www.phmsa.dot.gov/staticfiles/PHMSA/PipelineFailureReports/Mid-Valley%20Pipeline%20HL%20TX%202010-03-01%20508.pdf |date=April 2, 2012 }} Pipeline and Hazardous Materials Safety Administration, November 7, 2011, accessed September 5, 2015, 31 pages</ref> * On March 2, 2010, Reno County 911 dispatch was notified about a natural gas leak in a 26-inch diameter interstate pipeline at Red Rock Road and Andre Road near [[Abbyville, Kansas]]. Twenty people were evacuated as a precaution. The leak was caused by a ruptured girth weld in the pipe owned by [[Southern Star Central Gas Pipeline]]. The pipe was manufactured in 1967.<ref name="auto5">PHMSA Pipeline Safety-Flagged Incidents for 2010-2017, PHMSA Pipeline Incident Flagged Files page, https://www.phmsa.dot.gov/data-and-statistics/pipeline/pipeline-incident-flagged-files, accessed 2018.01.10.</ref> * On March 15, a 24-inch gas pipeline burst, but did not ignite near [[Pampa, Texas]].<ref>{{cite web|first=Joe |last=Gamm |url=http://amarillo.com/stories/031610/new_news7.shtml |title=No injuries in gas line rupture north of Pampa |publisher=Amarillo Globe-News |date=March 16, 2010 |accessdate=April 2, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131028041341/http://amarillo.com/stories/031610/new_news7.shtml |archivedate=October 28, 2013 }}</ref> * On March 25, there was a release of 1700 barrels of [[Vacuum gas oil]] (VGO) from the FM-1 pipeline into an open in-ground valve pit and the surrounding area in the West Yard of the Sunoco, R&M [[Philadelphia]] refinery in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. The area was under the control of the Operator in a fenced off area that is off-limits to the public.<ref>{{cite web|title=Failure Investigation Report – Sunoco R&M Flange Gasket 03/25/2010 |url=http://www.phmsa.dot.gov/staticfiles/PHMSA/PipelineFailureReports/Sunoco%20RM%20HL%20PA%202010-03-25.pdf |accessdate=28 November 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170203111219/http://www.phmsa.dot.gov/staticfiles//PHMSA/PipelineFailureReports/Sunoco%20RM%20HL%20PA%202010-03-25.pdf |archivedate=February 3, 2017 }}</ref> * On April 5, a crude oil pipeline ruptured near [[Green River, Wyoming]]. At least {{convert|84,000|USgal|L}} of crude were spilled. Corrosion in the pipeline was the cause.<ref name="nwf">{{cite web |title=Fuel Oil Incident List |url=http://www.nwf.org/News-and-Magazines/Media-Center/News-by-Topic/Global-Warming/2010/~/media/PDFs/Global%20Warming/Reports/Full-Oil-Incident-List.ashx |accessdate=October 30, 2016 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100803143750/http://www.nwf.org/News-and-Magazines/Media-Center/News-by-Topic/Global-Warming/2010/~/media/PDFs/Global%20Warming/Reports/Full-Oil-Incident-List.ashx |archivedate=August 3, 2010}}</ref> * On April 13, a flash fire occurred as a result of incorrect operations while operator and contract employees were conducting planned maintenance at the Seymour Terminal of the Enterprise Products Operating Company, LLC(EPCO) located in [[Jackson County, Indiana]]. Two EPCO employees and two contract employees were injured.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.phmsa.dot.gov/staticfiles/PHMSA/DownloadableFiles/Files/Pipeline/Failure%20Reports/129705_FIR_TEPPCO_Seymour%20IN_2010-04-13_Final%20[Redacted%20for%20Internet.pdf|title=Failure Investigation Report—TE Products Pipeline Company, LLC (TEPPCO)—Incorrect Operations|publisher=}}</ref> * On April 14, 2010, at an Enogex natural gas compressor station in [[Bennington, Oklahoma]], during construction tie-ins related to an expansion project, a contract employee was injured as a result of a flash fire which immediately extinguished itself. The contract employee's injuries required in-patient hospitalization. The cause of the accident was, in part, miscommunication between two crews working in the station at the same time.<ref name="auto5"/> * On April 23, a pipeline ruptured near [[Niles, Kansas]], due to previous excavation damage. About 1,659 barrels of natural gasoline were lost.<ref name="ens-newswire.com">{{cite web|url=http://ens-newswire.com/2012/06/04/pipeline-companies-fined-1-million-for-spills-in-three-states/ |title=– Pipeline Companies Fined $1 Million for Spills in Three States – ENS |work=ens-newswire.com |accessdate=January 18, 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160203115900/http://ens-newswire.com/2012/06/04/pipeline-companies-fined-1-million-for-spills-in-three-states/ |archivedate=February 3, 2016 }}</ref> * On May 10, 2010, at [[Swifton, Arkansas]], a Mississippi River Transmission Corporation employee arrived at the Swifton M&R station and found the regulator engulfed in flames, evidently from a direct hit by a lightning strike which perforated the equipment.<ref name="auto5"/> * On May 29, an [[Amoco]] pipeline leaked nearly 89,000 gallons of gasoline into a farm field along Quarterline Road. The leak occurred in [[Constantine Township]], [[St. Joseph County, Michigan]]. The cause was from a manufacturing defect in the pipe.<ref name="dot6">{{cite web|url=http://primis.phmsa.dot.gov/comm/reports/operator/OperatorIM_opid_395.html?nocache=1547#_Incidents_tab_3 |title=PHMSA: Stakeholder Communications – Operator Information |author= |date= |work=dot.gov |accessdate=May 23, 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160307180912/http://primis.phmsa.dot.gov/comm/reports/operator/OperatorIM_opid_395.html?nocache=1547 |archivedate=March 7, 2016 }}</ref> * On June 7, a 36-inch Enterprise natural gas pipeline leaked, exploded and started a fire in [[Johnson County, Texas]] when it was disturbed by workers installing poles for electrical lines. The mapping of subsurface utilities was inadequate, leading to inaccurate maps. Confusion over the location and status of the construction work led to the pipeline not being marked beforehand. These inaccuracies led to a miscommunication between the locator and the excavator, As a result, one worker was killed and seven were injured. The pipe was manufactured and installed in 1970.<ref>PHMSA Pipeline Safety-Flagged Incidents (2010-present), PHMSA Pipeline Incident Flagged Files page, https://www.phmsa.dot.gov/data-and-statistics/pipeline/pipeline-incident-flagged-files, accessed 2018.01.10.</ref><ref name="texasobserver.org">{{cite web|last=Wilder |first=Forrest |url=http://www.texasobserver.org/cover-story/the-fire-down-below |title=The Fire Down Below |publisher=The Texas Observer |date=November 26, 2010 |accessdate=April 2, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120925193438/http://www.texasobserver.org///cover-story/the-fire-down-below |archivedate=September 25, 2012 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.platts.com/RSSFeedDetailedNews/RSSFeed/HeadlineNews/NaturalGas/6158630|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120907022650/http://www.platts.com/RSSFeedDetailedNews/RSSFeed/HeadlineNews/NaturalGas/6158630|deadurl=yes|title=Platts: RSS Feed Detailed News|date=September 7, 2012|archivedate=September 7, 2012|publisher=}}</ref> * On June 8, construction workers hit an unmarked 14-inch gas gathering pipeline near [[Darrouzett, Texas]]. Two workers were killed.<ref name="texasobserver.org" /><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.newschannel10.com/Global/story.asp?S=12621597 |title=Another Gas Pipeline Explosion in Texas Kills 2 – KFDA – NewsChannel 10 / Amarillo News, Weather, Sports |publisher=Newschannel10.com |date=June 9, 2010 |accessdate=April 2, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131027205148/http://www.newschannel10.com/Global/story.asp?S=12621597 |archivedate=October 27, 2013 }}</ref> * The [[Red Butte Creek oil spill]]. On June 12, a [[Chevron Corporation|Chevron]] crude oil pipeline, damage by lightning, ruptured, causing {{convert|800|oilbbl|m3}} of crude to spill into Red Butte Creek in [[Salt Lake City, Utah]]. Crude then flowed into a pond in [[Liberty Park (Salt Lake City)|Liberty Park]].<ref>{{cite web|title=CPF 5-2010-5028 |url=http://primis.phmsa.dot.gov/comm/reports/enforce/documents/520105028/520105028_NOPV%20PCP%20PCO_11012010.pdf?nocache=2771 |accessdate=28 November 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304062805/http://primis.phmsa.dot.gov/comm/reports/enforce/documents/520105028/520105028_NOPV%20PCP%20PCO_11012010.pdf?nocache=2771 |archivedate=March 4, 2016 }}</ref> * On July 5, a landowner operating a bulldozer hit an 8-inch LPG/propane pipeline near [[Thomson, Georgia]]. Later, the propane fumes ignited, killing the adult son of the landowner, and igniting fires that destroyed a trailer house and woodlands.<ref>{{cite web|title=Failure Investigation Report – Dixie Pipeline Company 8‐inch Propane Pipeline Release 07/05/2010 |url=http://www.phmsa.dot.gov/staticfiles/PHMSA/PipelineFailureReports/Dixie_HL_GA_20100705.pdf |accessdate=28 November 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161002041852/http://www.phmsa.dot.gov/staticfiles/PHMSA/PipelineFailureReports/Dixie_HL_GA_20100705.pdf |archivedate=October 2, 2016 }}</ref> * On July 26, the [[Kalamazoo River oil spill]]: Enbridge Energy Partners LLP ([[Enbridge]]), reported that a {{convert|30|in|adj=on}} pipeline belonging to Enbridge burst in [[Marshall, Michigan]]. Enbridge had numerous alarms from the affected Line 6B, but controllers thought the alarms were from phase separation, and the leak was not reported to Enbridge for 17 hours. Enbridge estimates over {{convert|800,000|USgal|L}} of crude oil leaked into Talmadge Creek, a waterway that feeds the [[Kalamazoo River]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.epa.gov/enbridgespill/index.html |title=U.S. EPA "EPA Response to Enbridge Spill in Michigan" |publisher=Epa.gov |date= |accessdate=April 2, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130413130556/http://www.epa.gov/enbridgespill/index.html |archivedate=April 13, 2013 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://issuu.com/toledoblade/docs/07302010_the_blade |title=Archived copy |accessdate=May 14, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121007172122/http://issuu.com/toledoblade/docs/07302010_the_blade |archivedate=October 7, 2012}}</ref> whereas EPA reports over 1,139,569 gallons of oil have been recovered as of November 2011.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://epa.gov/enbridgespill/ |title=EPA Response to Enbridge Spill in Michigan | US EPA |publisher=Epa.gov |date= |accessdate=April 2, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130327022924/http://www.epa.gov/enbridgespill/ |archivedate=March 27, 2013 }}</ref> On July 27, 2010, an Administrative Order was issued by U.S. EPA requiring the performance of removal actions in connection with the facility. The Order requires Enbridge to immediately conduct removal of a discharge or to mitigate or prevent a substantial threat of a discharge of oil and to submit a Work Plan for the cleanup activities that was to include a Health and Safety Plan,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.battlecreekenquirer.com/assets/pdf/A5162632817.PDF |title=U.S. EPA REMOVAL ADMINISTRATIVE ORDER UNDER SECTION 311(c) OF THE CLEAN WATER ACT, REGION 5 |format=PDF |date= |accessdate=April 2, 2013}}{{dead link|date=May 2016}}</ref> as required by 29 CFR 1910.120 ([[HAZWOPER]]). In 2012, the NTSB later cited known but unrepaired cracks and external corrosion as the cause.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ntsb.gov/news/2012/120710.html |title=Press Release July 10, 2012 |publisher=Ntsb.gov |date= |accessdate=April 2, 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130403031649/http://www.ntsb.gov/news/2012/120710.html |archivedate=April 3, 2013}}</ref> * On August 10, the U.S. [[Environmental Protection Agency]] (EPA) and the [[Justice Department]] announced that [[Plains All American Pipeline]] and several of its operating subsidiaries have agreed to spend approximately $41 million to upgrade {{convert|10,420|mi|km}} of crude oil pipeline operated in the United States. The settlement resolves Plains' [[Clean Water Act]] violations for ten crude oil spills in Texas, Louisiana, Oklahoma, and Kansas, and requires the company to pay a $3.25 million civil penalty.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.epa.gov/compliance/resources/cases/civil/cwa/plainspipeline.html |title=Plains All American Pipeline Settlement | Compliance and Enforcement | US EPA |publisher=Epa.gov |date= |accessdate=April 2, 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130413233436/http://www.epa.gov/compliance/resources/cases/civil/cwa/plainspipeline.html |archivedate=April 13, 2013}}</ref> * On August 17, smell from a mixture of gasoline and diesel fuel were detected in [[Hammond, Indiana]]. The source was from a leaking [[Amoco]]/[[BP]] pipeline in the area, and about 38,000 gallons of the mixture was released. About 5,000 gallons of the spillage was not recovered. The cause was external corrosion to the pipeline.<ref name="dot6"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nwitimes.com/news/local/lake/hammond/hammond-officials-deal-with-oil-leak/article_0227a3a0-e07d-5309-bf82-197fa4d8a0fb.html|title=Hammond officials deal with oil leak|author=Times Staff|date=August 18, 2010|work=nwitimes.com|accessdate=May 23, 2016}}</ref> * On August 24, a gas compressor station in [[Shongaloo, Louisiana]] injured one worker.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.katc.com/news/1-injured-in-gas-compressor-station-explosion1/ |title=1 Injured in Gas Compressor Station Explosion | KATC.com | Acadiana-Lafayette, Louisiana |publisher=KATC.com |date= |accessdate=April 2, 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131027221418/http://www.katc.com/news/1-injured-in-gas-compressor-station-explosion1/ |archivedate=October 27, 2013}}</ref> * On August 25, a construction crew installing a gas pipeline in [[Roberts County, Texas]] hit an unmarked pipeline, seriously burning one man.<ref>{{cite web|first=Joe |last=Gamm |url=http://amarillo.com/stories/082610/web_rigaccident.shtml |title=Canadian man injured in pipeline accident |publisher=Amarillo Globe-News |date=August 26, 2010 |accessdate=April 2, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131028040826/http://amarillo.com/stories/082610/web_rigaccident.shtml |archivedate=October 28, 2013 }}</ref> * On August 27, an LPG pipeline leaked in [[Gilboa, New York]], forcing the evacuation of 23 people. The cause was [[stress corrosion cracking]]. There were no injuries or ignition.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://thedailystar.com/localnews/x2007170914/Liquid-propane-pipeline-set-to-reopen-in-January |title=Liquid propane pipeline set to reopen in January " Local News " ''The Daily Star'', Oneonta, NY – otsego county news, delaware county news, oneonta news, oneonta sports |publisher=Thedailystar.com |date=December 17, 2010 |accessdate=April 2, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=CPF No. 1-2010-5008H |url=http://primis.phmsa.dot.gov/comm/reports/enforce/documents/120105008H/120105008H_Amended%20CAO_11242010.pdf |accessdate=28 November 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170211130155/https://primis.phmsa.dot.gov/Comm/Reports/enforce/documents/120105008H/120105008H_Amended%20CAO_11242010.pdf |archivedate=February 11, 2017 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Failure Investigation Report Enterprise Products Propane Line Crack Failure Date 8/27/2010 |url=http://www.phmsa.dot.gov/staticfiles/PHMSA/PipelineFailureReports/Enterprise%20HL%20NY%202010-08-27%20508.pdf |accessdate=28 November 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170211085148/http://phmsa.dot.gov/staticfiles/PHMSA/PipelineFailureReports/Enterprise%20HL%20NY%202010-08-27%20508.pdf |archivedate=February 11, 2017 }}</ref> * On September 9, 2010 [[San Bruno pipeline explosion|a 30-inch diameter high pressure natural gas pipeline exploded]] in [[San Bruno, California]], a suburb of San Francisco. The blast destroyed 38 homes and damaged 120 more. More than a hundred people were evacuated. Eight died and at least 50 were injured. Ten acres of brush also burned. Later, [[PG&E]] was unable to supply the [[California Public Utilities Commission]] with documents on how PG&E established pressure limits on some of its gas transmission pipelines. It was also revealed that this pipeline had 26 leaks between Milpitas and San Francisco during the time of 1951 to 2009, with some of the leak causes listed in records as "unknown". Later hydrostatic testing of the pipeline that failed found a pinhole leak, and a previously damaged section blew out.<ref>{{cite news|last=Wittenstein |first=Jeran |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2010-09-10/san-francisco-neighborhood-engulfed-by-fire-after-gas-pipeline-explosion.html |title=Gas Explosion Engulfs Houses in San Francisco suburb of San Bruno |publisher=Bloomberg.com |date=September 10, 2010 |accessdate=April 2, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121103145956/http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2010-09-10/san-francisco-neighborhood-engulfed-by-fire-after-gas-pipeline-explosion.html |archivedate=November 3, 2012 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mercurynews.com/news/ci_16041191 |title=San Bruno explosion and fire kills 4, destroys 38 homes |publisher=Mercurynews.com |date=September 12, 2010 |accessdate=April 2, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121002215053/http://www.mercurynews.com/news/ci_16041191 |archivedate=October 2, 2012 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Worth |first=Katie |url=http://www.sfexaminer.com/local/bay-area/2011/03/pge-threatened-fines-1-million-pipeline-data |title=PG&E threatened with fines of $1 million for pipeline data | Katie Worth | Bay Area | San Francisco Examiner |publisher=Sfexaminer.com |date= |accessdate=April 2, 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130515150525/http://www.sfexaminer.com/local/bay-area/2011/03/pge-threatened-fines-1-million-pipeline-data |archivedate=May 15, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2011/10/22/MNU41LFO41.DTL |work=The San Francisco Chronicle |first=Jaxon |last=Van Derbeken |title=PG&E knew of many leaks in San Bruno pipeline |date=October 24, 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111231043835/http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=%2Fc%2Fa%2F2011%2F10%2F22%2FMNU41LFO41.DTL |archivedate=December 31, 2011 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2011/11/07/pacific-gas-electric-pipeline-bursts_n_1080280.html |work=Huffington Post |title=Pacific Gas & Electric Pipeline Bursts During Test, Closing Freeway |date=November 7, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111108052340/http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2011/11/07/pacific-gas-electric-pipeline-bursts_n_1080280.html |archivedate=November 8, 2011}}</ref> The pipe was manufactured in 1949.<ref>PHMSA Pipeline Safety-Flagged Incidents (2010-2017), www.phmsa.dot.govdata-and-statisticspipelinepipeline-incident-flagged-files, accessed 2017.12.29.</ref> * On September 9, a 20-inch diameter [[Columbia Gas Transmission]] Company pipeline failed in [[Lawrence County, Kentucky]]. While there was no fire or evacuations, the condition of this uncoated, non-cathodic protected, unknown grade pipeline caused PHMSA to enter into a Consent Order to eventually replace this pipeline.<ref>{{cite web|title=CPF 2-2010-1010S |url=http://primis.phmsa.dot.gov/comm/reports/enforce/documents/220101010S/220101010S_Notice%20of%20Proposed%20Safety%20Order_09302010.pdf |accessdate=28 November 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170211200004/https://primis.phmsa.dot.gov/comm/reports/enforce/documents/220101010S/220101010S_Notice%20of%20Proposed%20Safety%20Order_09302010.pdf |archivedate=February 11, 2017 }}</ref> * On September 28, a repair crew was working on a corroded gas pipe in [[Cairo, Georgia]], when the line exploded. One crew member was killed, and three others burned.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wctv.tv/home/headlines/Investigation_Report_Released_for_Cairo_Gasline_Explosion_112962719.html |title=Investigation Report Released for Cairo Gasline Explosion |publisher=Wctv.tv |date=January 5, 2011 |accessdate=April 2, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130907133014/http://www.wctv.tv/home/headlines/Investigation_Report_Released_for_Cairo_Gasline_Explosion_112962719.html |archivedate=September 7, 2013 }}</ref> * On October 11, equipment failure on Centurion Pipeline caused it to fail in [[Levelland, Texas]], releasing about 428,000 gallons of crude oil.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://primis.phmsa.dot.gov/comm/reports/operator/OperatorIM_opid_31888.html?nocache=1274#_Incidents_tab_4|title=PHMSA: Stakeholder Communications - Operator Information|website=primis.phmsa.dot.gov}}</ref> * On October 15, a natural gas pipeline under construction in [[Grand Prairie, Texas]] was running a [[pigging|cleaning pig]] without a pig "trap" at the end of the pipe. The 150 pound pig was expelled from the pipeline with enough force to fly {{convert|500|ft|m}}, and crash through the side of a house. No one was injured.<ref>{{cite web|last=Shipp |first=Brett |url=http://www.wfaa.com/news/local/Pipeline-Flying-Pig-crashes-through-Grand-Prairie-home-105387413.html |title=Pipeline 'pig' crashes through Grand Prairie home | wfaa.com | Dallas – Fort Worth Local News |publisher=wfaa.com |date=October 20, 2010 |accessdate=April 2, 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130126024404/http://www.wfaa.com/news/local/Pipeline-Flying-Pig-crashes-through-Grand-Prairie-home-105387413.html |archivedate=January 26, 2013}}</ref> * On November 8, 2010, near [[Tioga, North Dakota]], Aevenia Energy contracted to plow electrical cables underground from an oil well location owned by [[Amerada Hess]] Corporation across a wheat field to a power pole. The crew consisted of two bulldozer operators and one employee walking near the plow. Plowing started at the oil well location and had gone about 260 feet when it struck a Williston Basin Interstate Pipeline Company natural gas transmission line. The 8-inch diameter pipeline, operating at approximately 650 psig, failed after being struck by the plow, killing the person who was standing on the ground near the rupture. The two bulldozer operators jumped off their equipment and ran from the escaping gas. The force of the jetting gas blew the person on the ground 80 feet. None of the parties made a one-call notification prior to the start of the project. Two pipeline marker posts were visible from the access road into the site; the closest about 517 feet south of the rupture.<ref>PHMSA Pipeline Safety-Flagged Incidents for 2010-2017,PHMSA Pipeline Incident Flagged Files page, https://www.phmsa.dot.gov/data-and-statistics/pipeline/pipeline-incident-flagged-files, accessed 2018.01.10.</ref> * On November 12, three men working on natural gas lines were injured when a pipeline ruptured in [[Monroe, Louisiana]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.katc.com/news/natural-gas-pipeline-ruptures-injures-3/ |title=Natural gas pipeline ruptures, injures 3 | KATC.com | Acadiana-Lafayette, Louisiana |publisher=KATC.com |date= |accessdate=April 2, 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130825223813/http://www.katc.com/news/natural-gas-pipeline-ruptures-injures-3/ |archivedate=August 25, 2013}}</ref> * On November 30, a [[Tennessee Gas Pipeline]] 30-inch diameter gas pipeline failed at [[Natchitoches, Louisiana]]. There was no fire, but the pipe, which was manufactured in 1948, had a Magnetic Flux smart pig test earlier in the year that indicated no flaws. The failure was at a crack in a wrinkle bend which may have been stressed by shifting soil. The deadly 1965 gas pipeline accident had occurred on a different pipeline owned by the same company nearby.<ref>{{cite web|title=CPF No. 4-2010-1007H |url=http://primis.phmsa.dot.gov/comm/reports/enforce/documents/420101007H/420101007H_CAO_12032010.pdf |accessdate=28 November 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161226084530/http://primis.phmsa.dot.gov/comm/reports/enforce/documents/420101007H/420101007H_CAO_12032010.pdf |archivedate=December 26, 2016 }}</ref> * On December 1, a valve on a crude oil pipeline leaked about {{convert|500|oilbbl|m3}} of crude in [[Salt Lake City, Utah]]. This failure was only 100 yards from a June 2010 failure on the same pipeline.<ref>{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.sltrib.com/sltrib/home/50804000-76/chevron-pipeline-leak-lake.html.csp |title=Was Chevron's response too slow? | The Salt Lake Tribune |publisher=Sltrib.com |date=December 3, 2010 |accessdate=April 2, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121009050613/http://www.sltrib.com/sltrib/home/50804000-76/chevron-pipeline-leak-lake.html.csp |archivedate=October 9, 2012 }}</ref> * On December 2, a pipeline was discovered leaking gasoline near [[Livingston, Illinois]].<ref>{{cite web |title=Pipeline Discovered Leaking Gasoline |url=http://abclocal.go.com/wls/story?id=7836222&section=news/local/illinois |accessdate=May 14, 2012}}{{dead link|date=May 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref> * On December 8, at [[East Bernard, Texas]], a 24-inch diameter [[Tennessee Gas Pipeline]] exploded, blasting a 12-foot section of ruptured pipe 295 feet and caused $715,000 in property damage. It took 6 hours for the pipe system to blow down. The cause of the leak was a full guillotine failure of the pipe caused by internal corrosion micro-biologically induced due to moisture in the pipe.<ref>{{cite web|title=Failure Investigation Report – Tennessee Gas Pipeline Co. ‐ Internal Corrosion Failure Date 12/08/2010 |url=http://www.phmsa.dot.gov/staticfiles/PHMSA/PipelineFailureReports/TGP_GT_TX_20101208.pdf |accessdate=28 November 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170130190444/http://www.phmsa.dot.gov/staticfiles//PHMSA/PipelineFailureReports/TGP_GT_TX_20101208.pdf |archivedate=January 30, 2017 }}</ref> The pipe was manufactured in 1948.<ref name="auto5"/> * On December 17, a gas line fire and explosion just outside [[Corpus Christi, Texas]] city limits left one person critically injured. A man was working on removing an abandoned pipeline when it exploded, and his face was severely burned.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.kiiitv.com/Global/story.asp?S=13706543 |title=Gas Line Fire Explosion Critically Burns Man's Face |location=South Texas |publisher=Kiiitv.com |date= |accessdate=April 2, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131027232548/http://www.kiiitv.com/Global/story.asp?S=13706543 |archivedate=October 27, 2013 }}</ref> * On December 21, a crude oil pipeline was discovered leaking into the Dominguez Channel in the Port of [[Los Angeles]]. Over 1,000 gallons of crude oil was recovered, but the pipeline company was alleged to have failed to report the spill to State or Federal pipeline authorities. A 61 count criminal complaint was later filed in this accident.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.presstelegram.com/crime/ci_19640101 |title=Long Beach pipeline company charged in oil spill |publisher=Press-Telegram |date= |accessdate=April 2, 2013}}</ref> * On December 24, 2010, a mechanical failure at a [[Texas Gas Transmission]] compressor station near [[Youngsville, Louisiana]], caused a gas leak that ignited and exploded in the middle of the night. The Texas Gas gas control center received alarms indicating fire, vibration, and emergency shutdown alarms were activated. The fire department and state police secured the site. Once cleared by the fire chief on site, Texas Gas personnel assessed the damage. The cause of the incident was compressor component malfunction. The metallurgical report determined that six of eight engine bolts failed due to high cycle fatigue. The equipment has been installed in 1965.<ref name="auto5"/> * On December 28, a pipeline at an underground gas storage facility in [[Covington County, Mississippi]] leaked, forcing the evacuation of about two dozen families for over a week.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wdam.com/Global/story.asp?S=13782362 |title=Covington evacuees still await word to return home – WDAM – Channel 7 – Serving Hattiesburg, Laurel and the Pine Belt This is to show the ease of editing these pages. |publisher=WDAM |date=March 29, 2013 |accessdate=April 2, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131028005706/http://www.wdam.com/Global/story.asp?S=13782362 |archivedate=October 28, 2013 }}</ref>
== References == {{reflist}} {{List of pipeline accidents in the United States|state=autocollapse}} [[Category:Lists of pipeline accidents in the United States]] [[Category:2010 disasters in the United States]]

page.title: List of renewable energy companies by stock exchange

revision.comment: Addition of a new publicly traded Cleantech company - Clear Blue
revision.text:
[[File:Re investment 1995-2007.jpg|thumb|Past industry growth (1995-2007)[[REN21]] (2008) [http://www.ren21.net/globalstatusreport/default.asp ''Renewables 2007 Global Status Report''] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080625103235/http://www.ren21.net/globalstatusreport/default.asp |date=2008-06-25 }} (Paris: REN21 Secretariat and Washington, DC:Worldwatch Institute).]] [[File:Re investment 2007-2017.jpg|thumb|Projected industry growth (2007-2017)Makower, J. Pernick, R. Wilder, C. (2008) [http://www.cleanedge.com/reports/reports-trends2008.php ''Clean Energy Trends 2008''] ([http://www.cleanedhe.com Clean Edge] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120414045511/http://www.cleanedhe.com/ |date=2012-04-14 }}, USA)]] Several '''renewable energy companies''' became listed on stock exchanges in the period after 2000. The early 21st century was a very productive time for the [[renewable energy industry]], since many governments set long term [[Mandatory renewable energy targets|renewable energy targets]]. Some chose to directly subsidize the renewables with [[feed-in tariff]]s and other temporary measures to bridge the gap to [[full cost accounting]] that would properly reward these technologies for their low emissions and lack of interference with [[ecosystem services]], and also to ensure some capacity and motivation to install conservation-focused [[smart grid]] technologies. [[Smart grid policy in the United States]] was especially important in driving renewable energy in that country (see also [[load shedding]], [[energy internet]], [[home area network]] and [[cleantech]] for more on the structure of the industry and why renewables vendors are closely aligned industrially and politically with the vendors of networking technology), [[smart appliance]]s and [[energy conservation]] software, and opposed in general to those of other "energy" firms, which effectively depend on the lack of this intelligence or accounting to appear competitive. For instance, coal vendors rely on a lack of accounting of about US$345 billion in harms done by coal to remain competitive in the US.https://www.reuters.com/article/2011/02/16/usa-coal-study-idUSN1628366220110216 In 2004 Russia ratified the [[United Nations|United Nations']] [[Kyoto Protocol]] and the first order under this agreement came into force for the period 2008 to 2012. The period from 2002 to 2008 was a period of rapid growth for the renewable energy industry with the [[Photovoltaics|photovoltaics industry]] experiencing an average of 60% growth per annum, the [[biodiesel]] industry 42% and the [[Wind energy|wind industry]] 25%. As of the end of 2007 the renewable energy industry was worth an estimated US $77.3 billion. As a result of this growth several companies listed [[Initial public offering|IPOs]]. Many public companies involved in the development of this industry and responsible for large market share do not participate exclusively in renewable energy and have been omitted for this list, most notable of these are [[BP Solar|BP]], [[GE Energy]] and [[Sharp Solar|Sharp]]. This list consists of companies whose ''primary'' produce is either renewable energy or renewable energy products and services. == List of publicly traded renewable energy companies == {| class="wikitable sortable" style="margin: 1em auto 1em auto" ! colspan=6 style=" text-size=110; text-align: center"|Public renewable energy companies listed by stock exchange and symbol |- ! style="width:300px;"|Company !width="90"|Exchange place !width="90"|Symbol !width="90"|IPO ! style="width:180px;"|Industry |- |[[7C Solarparken]] | style="text-align:center;"| [[Frankfurt]] | style="text-align:center;"| {{FWB|HRPK}} | style="text-align:center;"| - | style="text-align:center;"| Renewables |- |[[A2Z Group]] | style="text-align:center;"| [[Mumbai]] | style="text-align:center;"| {{BSE|533292}},

revision.comment: Rescuing 3 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v1.6.1)
Disambiguating links to [[Invasive]] (link changed to [[Invasive species]]) using [[User:Qwertyytrewqqwerty/DisamAssist|DisamAssist]].
revision.text:
These are '''lists of [[invasive species]]''' by country or region. A '''species''' is regarded as '''[[Invasive species|invasive]]''' if it has been introduced by human action to a location, area, or region where it did not previously occur naturally (i.e., is not a [[native species]]), becomes capable of establishing a breeding population in the new location without further intervention by humans, and becomes a pest in the new location, threatening agriculture and/or the local [[biodiversity]].
The term '''invasive species''' refers to a subset of those species defined as [[introduced species]], for which see [[List of introduced species]].
*[[List of globally invasive species]] **[[List of invasive species in Africa]] ***[[List of invasive species in South Africa]] ****[[List of invasive plant species in South Africa]] **[[List of invasive species in Asia]] ***[[Invasive species in Japan]] **[[List of invasive species in Oceania]] ***[[List of invasive species in Australasia]] ****[[List of invasive species in Australia]] ****[[Invasive species in New Zealand]] ***[[Invasive species in Hawaii]] ****[[List of bird species introduced to the Hawaiian Islands]] ****[[List of invasive plant species in Hawaii]] **[[List of invasive species in Europe]] ***[[Invasive species in the British Isles]] ***[[List of invasive species in Italy]] ***[[List of invasive species in Portugal]] *[[List of invasive species in North America]] **[[Invasive grasses of North America]] **[[Invasive species in the United States]] ***[[List of invasive species in California]] ****[[List of invasive plant species in California]] ***[[List of invasive species in Florida]] ****[[List of invasive species in the Everglades]] ****[[List of invasive marine fish in Florida]] ****[[List of invasive plant species in Florida]] ****[[Burmese pythons in Florida]] ***[[List of invasive plant species in Arizona]] ***[[List of invasive plant species in the Indiana Dunes]] ***[[List of invasive plant species in Maryland]] ***[[List of invasive plant species in Nevada]] ***[[List of invasive plant species in New Jersey]] ***[[List of invasive plant species in New Mexico]] ***[[List of invasive plant species in Utah]] ***[[List of invasive plant species in West Virginia]] ***[[List of invasive plant species in Wisconsin]] **[[Invasive species in South America|List of invasive species in South America]] ***[[List of invasive species in Colombia]]
==See also== * [[List of globally invasive species]] * [[List of introduced bird species]] * [[List of introduced mammal species]] * [[List of introduced species]] * [[Introduced species]]
==External links== *[http://www.issg.org/database/species/List.asp ISSG Database: List of all species] * [http://www.invasivespeciesinfo.gov/ National Invasive Species Information Center], National Invasive Species Information Center, [[United States National Agricultural Library]]. Lists general information and resources for invasive species. * [http://tib.islandconservation.org/ Threatened Island Biodiversity database (TIB)]
